title: The Cost of a Bet After PASPA
journal: ISU Red - Research and eData (Illinois State University)
abstract: My research examines this question by studying bookmaker “margins,” the built-in cost that bettors pay on every wager. Despite margins being a core component of how sportsbooks generate revenue, they have received relatively little academic attention. I analyzed 87,584 bookmaker-sport-month observat
sub_theme: bookmaker margins, PASPA repeal impact
ai_summary: Analysis of 87,584 bookmaker-sport-month observations across 610 leagues worldwide reveals that bookmaker margins rose sharply following the 2018 repeal of PASPA, reflecting increased transaction costs for bettors.

title: Uniform Neuromuscular Responses Across Varied Blood Flow Restriction Training Strategies
journal: The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: Abstract Howard, MA, Rivera, PM, Lubiak, SM, Proppe, CE, Schmidt, JT, Rolnick, N, Shobe, ED, Fraifer, TL, and Hill, EC. Uniform neuromuscular responses across varied blood flow restriction training strategies. J Strength Cond Res XX(X): 000–000, 2025—The purpose of this investigation was to assess n
sub_theme: blood flow restriction training neuromuscular responses
ai_summary: In 17 recreationally active females, low-load blood flow restriction training with varied set and repetition schemes (1×75, 3×, 1× to failure) produced uniform neuromuscular responses via EMG, with single-set-to-failure protocol achieving maximal acute effects.

title: Injury Patterns and Trends in US Cheerleading: A Systematic Review of an Understudied Sport
abstract: Objective: To systematically compile and analyze studies on cheerleading-related injuries in the United States, with a focus on injury patterns and trends. Data Sources: PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials. Search terms included (“cheerleader” OR “cheerleading” OR “che
sub_theme: cheerleading injury patterns and trends
ai_summary: Systematic review of 14 studies covering 28,998 cheerleaders (96.5% female) identified 239,361 injuries with ankle injuries most common, followed by head/brain/neck injuries, predominantly during practice, highlighting need for standardized injury reporting systems.

title: Programa de desarrollo del conocimiento teórico en jóvenes futbolistas a través de la enseñanza comprensiva del deporte
abstract: Introduction: theoretical knowledge supports decision-making, autonomy, and reflective thinking. It plays a key role in the holistic development of young athletes, especially in sports like football, where constant interaction with the environment demands adaptive responses. To enhance these skills,
sub_theme: tactical understanding, Teaching Games for Understanding (TGfU)
ai_summary: A 13-session Teaching Games for Understanding (TGfU) program with reflective strategies significantly improved theoretical knowledge and tactical understanding in U12 football players.

title: The Effects of Acute Stroboscopic Training on Tennis Serve Return Accuracy
abstract: The effects of a single stroboscopic training session on anticipating tennis serve direction were explored. Intermediate tennis players in both the stroboscopic training ( n = 16) and control ( n = 16) conditions completed 40 pretest and 40 post-test service video clips, prompting them to indicate t
sub_theme: anticipation training, serve return
ai_summary: A single stroboscopic training session significantly improved serve direction anticipation accuracy in intermediate tennis players compared to controls, though reaction times showed no difference.

title: Agreement between muscle saturation breakpoints and lactate thresholds: Muscles comparison and sex difference in world‐class Nordic skiers
abstract: Abstract Near‐infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) has emerged as a potential alternative method for determination of breakpoints equivalent to lactate thresholds. However, the optimal NIRS location remains unclear, particularly in Nordic skiing, which requires both upper‐ and lower‐limb contributions. This
sub_theme: lactate threshold and muscle saturation breakpoints in Nordic skiing
ai_summary: Near-infrared spectroscopy breakpoints (BP2) on vastus lateralis, biceps femoris, and biceps brachii showed very good accuracy for detecting lactate threshold in world-class Nordic skiers, with no significant sex differences between 29 males and 23 females.

title: Hamstring-to-quadriceps fatigue ratio in female professional football players
abstract: Abstract Background The assessment of the hamstrings-to-quadriceps (H:Q) strength ratio using an isokinetic dynamometer is commonly performed throughout the football season and is frequently used as an indicator of potential lower-limb injury risk. However, these evaluations are typically conducted
sub_theme: hamstring-to-quadriceps fatigue ratio in female football players
ai_summary: In 15 professional female football players, a 30-repetition isokinetic fatigue test reduced hamstring-to-quadriceps strength ratio from 0.64 to 0.52, with greater hamstring fatigue (47% vs 34%), suggesting increased lower-limb injury risk when fatigued.

title: Differences in female athlete triad risk factors between Japanese and American female runners: A comparative study
abstract: Abstract Background Differences in female athlete triad risk factors between runners from Japan and the United States have not been explored. Objective To compare the prevalence of Triad risk factors and Triad components between female Japanese and American distance runners. Design Observational, cr
sub_theme: female athlete triad risk factors, Japan vs USA
ai_summary: Comparative study of 77 female distance runners (36 Japanese, 41 American) found Japanese runners had significantly lower bone mineral density and higher prevalence of energy deficiency (56% vs 32%) and stress fractures (50% vs 17%), despite similar BMI and menstrual patterns.

title: Subjectivity and moments of non-gendered embodiment: A discourse analysis of CrossFit women's bodies
journal: International Review for the Sociology of Sport
abstract: In sport, transgressing binary gender boundaries is especially challenging for women as physicality, muscularity and athleticism remain closely tied to male masculinity. In this feminist poststructural and posthumanist study, 14 South African women CrossFitters engaged in individual autophotographic
sub_theme: women's embodiment and gender identity in CrossFit
ai_summary: Foucauldian discourse analysis of 14 South African female CrossFitters reveals how muscularity discourses construct women's bodies through sexual desirability and muscular dilemma tensions, enabling non-gendered embodiment.

title: AI-enabled learning analytics use relates to physical literacy and engagement in university PE via smart teaching and personalised feedback
abstract: Digital transformation and AI-enabled learning analytics are reshaping higher education, and wearable-enabled analytics are increasingly used in embodied curricula such as university physical education (PE), but empirical evidence linking these systems to physical literacy remains limited. This stud
sub_theme: physical literacy, learning analytics, wearable technology, AI-enabled dashboards
ai_summary: Mixed-methods study of 1,182 Chinese university PE students demonstrates that AI-enabled wearable learning analytics improve physical literacy and engagement primarily through pedagogical processes (smart teaching and personalized feedback) rather than direct data exposure.

title: The Torque-Velocity Relationship and Second ACL Injury Risk
abstract: ABSTRACT Context: Anterior cruciate ligament injury results in an elevated risk of reinjury despite surgical reconstruction (ACLR). According to the torque-velocity relationship, muscle contraction velocity and torque production should be inversely related, but this is altered following ACLR. Object
sub_theme: ACL reinjury prediction, torque-velocity relationship
ai_summary: Quadriceps torque-velocity relationship measured via isokinetic testing significantly predicted ACL reinjury risk in 579 post-ACLR patients over 2+ years, with higher strength associated with increased reinjury odds.

title: Functional Training with Phygital Elements and Artificial Intelligence Integration
abstract: The article explores the integration of phygital sport technologies into the system of physical education. The prospects of applying artificial intelligence, computer vision, and gamification for modernizing the training process are considered. Particular attention is given to the development of ada
sub_theme: phygital technologies, AI integration in physical education, wearable sensors, gamification
ai_summary: Review of phygital and AI-powered training technologies including smart simulators, telemetry, and wearable sensors for modernizing sports and physical education with adaptive programs and gamification.

title: Developing while performing and performing while developing? A case study of an integrated talent development and high performance sport environment at Munster Rugby
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: The junior-to-senior transition presents persistent difficulty for elite sport, often exacerbated by poor integration between talent development and high-performance environments. This case study evaluated Munster Rugby's integrated model, which merged the academy and senior squad into a single trai
sub_theme: junior-to-senior transition, integrated talent development environment
ai_summary: Case study of Munster Rugby's integrated academy-senior squad model found full-time training accelerated learning and selection opportunities, but outcomes varied; success required individualized support and managing tension between winning and long-term development.

title: Integrating Unsupervised and Supervised Learning for the Prediction of Defensive Schemes in American football
abstract: Anticipating defensive coverage schemes is a crucial yet challenging task for offenses in American football. Because defenders' assignments are intentionally disguised before the snap, they remain difficult to recognize in real time. To address this challenge, we develop a statistical framework that
sub_theme: defensive scheme prediction, coverage recognition
ai_summary: Statistical framework integrating elastic net logistic regression and gradient-boosted trees with hidden Markov model features on player tracking data to predict defensive coverage schemes (man vs. zone) in American football.

title: Tennis Industry and Digital Transformation: Opportunities and Challenges
journal: International Journal of Education and Humanities
abstract: With the rapid development of digital technology, the sports industry, especially the tennis industry, is undergoing a historic transformation. This article will deeply analyze how the wave of digitalization is reshaping every aspect of the tennis industry, from event operations to audience experien
sub_theme: digital transformation in tennis industry
ai_summary: This article analyzes how digital transformation is reshaping the tennis industry across event operations, athlete training, audience experience, and marketing, proposing strategic recommendations for industry adoption.

title: Anxiety and depression in athletes of different levels without current injury: a systematic review with meta-analyses
abstract: ABSTRACT Exercise has been demonstrated to affect the prevention and treatment of anxiety and depression positively; however, athletes face an increased risk of mental health issues. Objective: The objective of this systematic review and meta-analysis (PROSPERO: CRDXXX) was to determine the prevalen
sub_theme: anxiety and depression prevalence in athletes
ai_summary: Systematic review and meta-analysis of athletes across all competitive levels found prevalence of moderate/severe anxiety at 16% (12,893 athletes), depression at 18% (19,290 athletes), and 12-month incidence of combined anxiety/depression at 40% (611 athletes).

title: External Load of Professional Female Soccer Players in the Competitive Microcycle: Influence of Playing Position and Contextual Variables
journal: The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: Abstract Sánchez-Abselam, O, González-Fernández, FT, Castillo-Rodríguez, A, and Onetti-Onetti, W. External load of professional female soccer players in the competitive microcycle: Influence of playing position and contextual variables. J Strength Cond Res XX(X): 000–000, 2026—Women's soccer has exp
sub_theme: external load by position and context
ai_summary: GPS analysis of 18 professional Spanish women's soccer players across 13 microcycles found significant positional differences in explosive distance and high-speed running, with contextual factors (opponent quality, match location) influencing external load demands.

title: FIFA Connect Adoption: A Mixed-Methods Study in Moroccan Women's Football
journal: Journal of Sports and Physical Education Studies
abstract: This study examines the adoption challenges of FIFA Connect within Moroccan women's football clubs with an aim of defining the factors that determine the use of technology as mandatory in structurally-dependent organizations. With Morocco on the verge of co-hosting the 2030 FIFA world cup, it is eve
sub_theme: technology adoption in women's football management
ai_summary: A mixed-methods study of Moroccan women's football clubs found that Information Quality was the strongest predictor of FIFA Connect adoption, while System Quality was critically underperforming, with structural dependency on men's clubs and inadequate training limiting digital transformation.

title: Ankle-GO Score to Identify Elite Basketball Players Who Will Suffer Lateral Ankle Sprain During a Competitive Season: A 1-Year Prospective Cohort Study
journal: The American Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Background: Lateral ankle sprain (LAS) is the most common injury in basketball, and identifying at-risk players is of high importance. Purpose: To evaluate the ability of the Ankle-GO score to identify elite basketball players who will suffer LAS during a competitive season as well as other potentia
sub_theme: lateral ankle sprain prediction
ai_summary: The Ankle-GO score, combining functional tests and self-reported questionnaires, successfully predicted lateral ankle sprain risk in elite basketball players, with scores <19 points and prior LAS history showing strongest predictive value.

title: Anthropometric Characteristics Associated with 2000 m Rowing Ergometer Performance in Adolescent Athletes
abstract: Background: Anthropometric characteristics are known determinants of rowing performance, particularly during adolescence, when rapid physical growth affects strength, leverage, and movement efficiency. Understanding how body size and proportionality relate to rowing output is essential for contextua
sub_theme: anthropometric determinants of rowing performance
ai_summary: Anthropometric variables—particularly height, body mass, muscle mass, and body surface area—are strongly associated with 2000 m ergometer performance in adolescent rowers, with similar correlation patterns observed in both males and females across eight countries.

title: Who sleeps worse and why? An analysis of sex, chrononutrition, anxiety, and sleep in adolescent athletes
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: This study investigated how anxiety and chrononutrition are related to sleep in male and female adolescent athletes. In total, 460 adolescent athletes (14.7 ± 1.5y; 38% female) completed the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-S), and Chrononutrition Profile Qu
sub_theme: sleep quality, anxiety, chrononutrition in adolescent athletes
ai_summary: In 460 adolescent athletes, anxiety was the strongest correlate of poor sleep quality, and the sex gap in sleep quality was largely explained by higher anxiety in females, with later breakfast timing independently associated with worse sleep.

title: Effects of a 3-week foam rolling warm-up intervention on ankle dorsiflexion measurements and jumping performance in young rhythmic gymnasts
journal: BMC Sports Science Medicine and Rehabilitation
abstract: Abstract Background Few studies have analyzed the medium- to long-term effects of warm-up protocols on biomechanical and performance parameters in athletes. This study evaluated the effects of a 3-week foam rolling (FR) protocol integrated into the initial phase of the warm-up on ankle dorsiflexion
sub_theme: foam rolling warm-up effects on jumping and ankle dorsiflexion
ai_summary: A 3-week foam rolling warm-up protocol in 26 young female rhythmic gymnasts significantly improved countermovement jump performance and angular dorsiflexion velocity, though not static ankle dorsiflexion range of motion.

title: Does Playing Time Impact Player Performance? A COVID-19 Natural Experiment
abstract: This paper assesses the effect of playing time on player performance within the Chinese Basketball Association. The outbreak of the COVID-19 prevented some foreign players from returning to their team during the 2019–2020 season and has led to an increase in playing time for domestic players in over
sub_theme: playing time effects on player performance, plus-minus, quantile regression
ai_summary: COVID-19 natural experiment in Chinese Basketball Association shows domestic players with increased playing time exhibit significantly improved performance measured by plus-minus, field goal percentage, and points per minute with persistent gains beyond the immediate season.

title: Injury characteristics, outcome, and return to play after ankle sprains and Achilles tendon ruptures in tennis
journal: South African Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Background: Ankle sprains and acute Achilles tendon ruptures are common injuries among recreational tennis players. Objectives: This study investigated the specific cause, return to play, and ability to play tennis after an ankle sprain and Achilles tendon rupture. Methods: Patients who sustained an
sub_theme: ankle sprains, Achilles tendon ruptures, return to play
ai_summary: Retrospective study of recreational tennis players with ankle sprains and Achilles tendon ruptures shows 90% return-to-play rate for ankle sprains at mean 3.6 months versus 29% for Achilles ruptures, with most non-returners citing fear of re-injury rather than functional limitations.

title: The 50 Highest Cited Papers on Patellofemoral Instability
abstract: The aim of this research was to identify the 50 articles most frequently referenced concerning patellofemoral instability (PFI) and to analyze their features. A search was performed in the Thomson ISI Web of Science using keywords such as “patellofemoral instability,” “patellar instability,” “patell
sub_theme: patellofemoral instability research trends
ai_summary: A bibliometric analysis of the 50 most-cited papers on patellofemoral instability found that 84% were clinical studies with level IV evidence, predominantly published in the 2000s in the American Journal of Sports Medicine, reflecting clinical focus over basic science.

title: Effects of a 12-weeks pelvic floor exercises program on sports performance of female athletes: An exploratory randomized clinical trial
abstract: A 12-week app-based PFMT may reduce the perceived impact of PFD on sQoL in female athletes. In CMJ, biofeedback showed higher mean power only compared with control. Future studies should confirm these effects in larger, sport-specific cohorts.
sub_theme: pelvic floor dysfunction, female athletes, sport performance
ai_summary: A 12-week app-based pelvic floor muscle training program in female athletes reduced perceived impact of pelvic floor dysfunction on quality of life, with biofeedback showing higher countermovement jump power compared to control.

title: Survey Study of a Division-I Women’s Cross-Country Team Reveals Limited Participation in Pre-Collegiate Strength Training: Is There an Opportunity to Improve Training Modalities and Health Outcomes?
journal: Journal of Orthopaedic Science and Research
abstract: Background: While aerobic exercise modalities are the cornerstone cross-country (XC) training, Strength and resistance Training (ST) has become increasingly popular and is widely considered to be beneficial to XC athletes when used appropriately. The purpose of this research was to investigate pre-c
sub_theme: bone stress injuries, strength training in youth
ai_summary: Survey of 11 Division-I female cross-country athletes found only 36% participated in pre-collegiate strength training, highlighting an opportunity to reduce bone stress injuries through earlier resistance training implementation.

title: Athletic Pubalgia (Sports Hernia): Narrative Review of Pathophysiology, Diagnosis, and Management
abstract: Background. Athletic pubalgia is a frequent yet poorly defined cause of chronic groin pain in athletes. It is not associated with a true inguinal hernia but results from overload-related injury to the musculotendinous and fascial structures responsible for pelvic and core stability. Heterogeneous te
sub_theme: athletic pubalgia, groin pain, core stability
ai_summary: Narrative review synthesizes evidence on athletic pubalgia pathophysiology, diagnosis via MRI, and management strategies showing conservative treatment as first-line therapy with surgery offering superior outcomes for refractory cases.

title: Development of offensive tactical skills in volleyball
abstract: This study investigates the effectiveness of a specialized methodology aimed at developing offensive tactical skills in volleyball players. The purpose of the research was to determine the impact of game-based and situational training methods on the tactical efficiency of attacking players. The peda
sub_theme: offensive tactical skills development through game-based training
ai_summary: A 12-week pedagogical experiment demonstrates that game-based, situational, and video-feedback training significantly improves offensive tactical efficiency and attack success rates in college-age volleyball players compared to controls.

abstract: The outcome of a rugby sevens match largely depends on the physical preparedness of female athletes. Speed abilities play a significant role in the structure of physical training of qualified female rugby sevens players.The purpose of the study was to determine indicators of speed abilities in quali
sub_theme: speed abilities, female rugby sevens, physical preparedness
ai_summary: Assessment of 30 female rugby sevens players found that sprint performance (50m, 10m, 20m, 40m splits) and vertical jump achieved 76-97% of world-class standards, with highest relative performance in 20-40m sprints (94-97%) compared to elite benchmarks.

title: Highest oxygen consumption prediction by forced vital capacity in athletes
abstract: Abstract Purpose Static spirometry parameters may offer practical alternatives to estimate maximum oxygen consumption (V̇O 2max ) in athletic populations. This study evaluated forced vital capacity (FVC) as a predictor of V̇O 2max across different sports, developing prediction equations for field-ba
sub_theme: VO2max prediction, spirometry, field assessment
ai_summary: LASSO regression on 422 athletes (cycling, swimming, triathlon, multisport) developed a practical VO2max prediction equation using forced vital capacity and gender (R²=0.690, SEE=0.65 L·min⁻¹), with sport-specific analysis showing highest accuracy in swimmers (R²=0.893).

ai_summary: A theoretical analysis demonstrates that training young footballers on varied surfaces (sand, concrete, natural/artificial grass) effectively develops physical, technical, and tactical abilities through differential adaptation.

title: Reoperation Rates for Medial, Lateral, and Bicompartmental Meniscal Tears Managed During Primary Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction
journal: The American Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Background: Meniscal tears occur at the time of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury in 55% to 65% of patients. These tears exhibit different healing patterns and behavior compared with meniscal tears in a stable knee. The optimal management of different medial, lateral and bicompartmental tears
sub_theme: meniscal tears, ACL reconstruction, surgical treatment, return to play
ai_summary: Cohort study of 1137 athletes with concomitant meniscal tears during ACL reconstruction, finding low reoperation rates for in situ management (1.3-3.2%) but higher rates for meniscal repair (14.8% medial), with implications for RTP outcomes.

title: Diplomasi Publik Indonesia Melalui Esport: Studi Kasus M4 World Championship 2023
journal: Dialogika Jurnal Penelitian Komunikasi dan Sosialisasi

Indonesia’s role as the host of the M4 World Championship 2023 represents a significant example of
sub_theme: public diplomacy through esports
ai_summary: Qualitative case study of Indonesia's M4 World Championship 2023 demonstrates how esport events function as effective public diplomacy instruments through advocacy and cultural diplomacy functions to enhance international engagement and visibility.

title: Does the Soccer Training Method Interfere with Psychomotor Development? A Study in Bolivian Children
abstract: Scientific documents exist that directly address the relationship of the training method with soccer learning, but very few studies relate them to the contents of child psychomotor development. Therefore, the objective of the present study is to establish the relationship of the soccer training meth
sub_theme: psychomotor development, training methods
ai_summary: A descriptive correlational study of 75 Bolivian children aged 5-11 found that analytical soccer training methods prioritizing technique and tactics may interfere with harmonious psychomotor development, particularly affecting balance and coordination.

title: From Seasoned Vet to Space-Taker: Gendered Ageism in Coverage of Professional Basketball Player Diana Taurasi’s Final Season
abstract: This study examined coverage of 42-year-old professional basketball player Diana Taurasi during her final WNBA season. Age remains an underexplored element of identity in sports media research. An analysis informed by intersectionality found that media discourse made age meaningful through gendered
sub_theme: gendered ageism in sports media
ai_summary: Qualitative media analysis of Diana Taurasi's final WNBA season revealed gendered ageism in sports coverage, where female athletes' aging is framed through narratives of decline and intergenerational rivalry, perpetuating misogynistic and racist discourse.

title: Psychological skills training as a strategy to improve mental health and reduce perceived stress in university athletes
abstract: This study examined the effectiveness of a one-month Psychological Skills Training (PST) program in improving mental health and reducing perceived stress among university athletes. Twenty-one student-athletes (15 males and 6 females) from six faculties participated in eight structured PST sessions c
sub_theme: psychological skills training, stress reduction, mental health
ai_summary: A one-month psychological skills training program in 21 university athletes significantly reduced perceived stress scores (mean drop from 24.14 to 16.81, d=1.30), with high-stress prevalence declining from 38% to 4.8%.

title: Balance Assessments Using Smartphone Sensor Systems and a Clinician-Led Modified BESS Test in Soccer Athletes with Hip-Related Pain: An Exploratory Cross-Sectional Study
abstract: Background: The Balance Error Scoring System (BESS) is the most practiced static postural balance assessment tool, which relies on visual observation, and has been adopted as the gold standard in the clinic and field. However, the BESS can lead to missed and inaccurate diagnoses—because of its low i
sub_theme: balance assessment, hip-related pain, smartphone sensors
ai_summary: An exploratory cross-sectional study of 64 soccer athletes used smartphone-based motion sensors to assess postural balance, finding anterior-posterior and mediolateral sway measurements during single-leg stance had acceptable-to-excellent discriminative validity (AUC=0.72-0.80) for identifying hip pain.

title: Hip Surgical Treatment Registry (HipSTR): The North American Hip Arthroscopy Registry—Who We Are Operating on and What We Are Doing; Findings in Its Inaugural Year 2023 With >1000 Patients
journal: The American Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Background: In 2023, the first North American Hip Arthroscopy Registry was released: the Hip Surgical Treatment Registry (HipSTR). HipSTR is a prospective web-based data collection registry designed to gather baseline patient information, procedural data, and surgical outcomes. Purpose: To present t
sub_theme: hip arthroscopy, femoroacetabular impingement, surgical registry
ai_summary: The inaugural HipSTR registry enrolled 1,098 hip arthroscopy patients (65% female, mean age 36.6 years) in 2023, with 315 identified as athletes; common findings included CAM lesions (45%), labral tears (43%), and acetabular chondral lesions (38%), with 98% of CAM patients receiving femoral osteoplasty.

title: Analysis of technical performance of pencak silat athletes in the sparring category of men's class c, men's class e and women's class b at malang state university
abstract: This research aims to find out the technical performance of pencak silat athletes in the sparring category of class C men, class E men and class B women of State University of Malang through performance analysis. This research uses descriptive qualitative methods with Visual Research Method techniqu
sub_theme: pencak silat technique, sparring performance
ai_summary: A qualitative video analysis of 22 pencak silat sparring matches across three athlete categories found the sickle kick was the dominant technique (33-39% of techniques used) with 70-85% success rate, with left-side kicks showing higher success than right-side.

ai_summary: A pedagogically-structured 10-12 week methodology using small-sided games effectively develops physical fitness and motor abilities in grades 7-9 students in rural school settings.

abstract: Abstract Purpose Lisfranc injuries are potentially career‐threatening for athletes, yet optimal management of unstable ligament and fracture‐dislocation injury patterns remains debated. This study integrates an international expert consensus with a systematic review to evaluate current surgical stra
sub_theme: Lisfranc injuries, return to play, surgical outcomes
ai_summary: Systematic review and international consensus on surgical treatment of Lisfranc injuries in elite athletes, finding suture button fixation superior to ORIF for unstable ligament injuries with higher success rates and lower complications.

title: Perceptions of Biomechanical Devices in Collegiate Baseball Pitchers and Training Staff: A Qualitative Study
abstract: Background Baseball players, coaches, and clinicians have sought to leverage biomechanical devices to inform training load and injury prevention. A novel biomechanical pitching sleeve and portable force plate have been proposed to track training load, kinetic, and kinematic data. The objective of th
sub_theme: wearable biomechanical devices, implementation barriers and facilitators
ai_summary: Qualitative study of collegiate baseball pitchers and training staff identified barriers (data interpretation, systemization challenges) and facilitators (individualized data, athlete empowerment, injury prevention appreciation) for adoption of wearable biomechanical monitoring devices.

title: Investigation into the role of digital tool as support for competency and skill development in higher education swimming lessons
abstract: Supporting learners in complex skill acquisition is a demanding process that requires substantial knowledge of the scientific principles and the individual, environmental, and task constraints defining each learner’s optimal movement execution. Future applied practitioners (sport scientists, coaches
sub_theme: digital tool effectiveness in swimming skill development
ai_summary: Pre-post study of 26 sport science students shows digital tool support produces statistically significant improvements in swimming performance (time and technique), self-assessment accuracy, and content knowledge, though gains are not correlated with tool usage frequency.

title: The Tartan pipeline: A 24-season longitudinal analysis of elite player development in professional Scottish football
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: Scotland has a proud footballing legacy marked by famous European successes and world-class players, yet recent decades have witnessed a sustained period of underperformance both domestically and internationally. Back-to-back European Championship qualifications, coupled with Scotland's qualificatio
sub_theme: elite player progression, talent pathways, longitudinal analysis
ai_summary: A 24-season longitudinal analysis of 2,671 Scottish professional footballers identified early debut-season involvement ('early trust') as the strongest predictor of elite player progression and senior international representation, more significant than academy pathway or early youth caps.

title: Faster, higher, stronger... safer? Questioning the commitment of international sport federations on safeguarding
abstract: Interpersonal violence against athletes (including physical, psychological, and sexual abuse, harassment, and neglect) long remained a blind spot for sport organisations (Mountjoy et al., 2016). For decades, the status quo allowed these violences to be overlooked or dismissed. Yet, this silence has
sub_theme: safeguarding and athlete protection governance
ai_summary: A mixed-methods study examining safeguarding policies and institutional responses of 40 international sport federations revealed significant heterogeneity in implementation maturity and a persistent lack of coherence or coordination in athlete protection mechanisms.

title: Management of first‐time shoulder dislocations: A survey of sport medicine physician perceptions
abstract: Abstract Purpose The purpose of this study was to survey sport medicine physicians globally to evaluate how they treat patients with a first‐time shoulder dislocation (FTSD), specifically exploring the most common management strategies, the evidence or guidelines guiding these decisions, and the inf
sub_theme: first-time shoulder dislocation management
ai_summary: A global survey of 326 sport medicine physicians found emerging consensus on first-time shoulder dislocation management (immobilization + physical therapy), though geographic variation persists in imaging and surgical decision-making is influenced by bony injury, patient age, and contact sport participation.

title: Gender Representation in Fitness Influencers: How Men and Women Convey Running Messages on Digital Platforms
journal: Indonesian Journal of Contemporary Multidisciplinary Research
abstract: This study examines gender representation in running-related Instagram content produced by fitness influencers in Indonesia. Using qualitative content analysis, the research analyzes selected posts and reels from male and female influencers to explore how running is framed through narrative, message
sub_theme: gender representation in running on social media
ai_summary: Content analysis of Indonesian fitness influencers' Instagram running posts reveals male influencers frame running as performance-oriented discipline while female influencers emphasize holistic well-being and community, reflecting gendered constructions of masculinity and femininity in digital sports culture.

title: Redefining Injury Severity in Youth Sports: Functional Inability to Walk as a Primary Severity Phenotype (n = 4,829)
abstract: Abstract Objectives Determinants of functional injury severity in young athletes remain incompletely understood. Conventional assumptions emphasize contact sport participation and skeletal immaturity as major drivers of severe injury; however, severity definitions based on surgery or time loss are s
sub_theme: injury severity, functional severity, lower-extremity injury phenotyping
ai_summary: In 4,829 youth athletes (≤22 years) with lower-extremity sports injury, early functional severity (inability to walk) was primarily associated with acute injury acuity and knee/ankle involvement (OR 31.1 and 2.73 respectively), not sport type or skeletal maturity.

title: Factors Influencing the Efficacy of Concurrent Training in Team Sports: A Narrative Review
abstract: Concurrent training (CT)—the integration of strength and endurance exercises within the same session or cycle—is widely implemented in team sports. However, its optimal configuration and the conditions under which the so-called “interference effect” occurs remain subjects of debate. This narrative r
sub_theme: concurrent training, strength and endurance integration
ai_summary: A narrative review of 13 experimental studies across team sports found that concurrent strength and endurance training can effectively enhance both capacities when strength precedes endurance or sessions are separated by ≥6 hours, though high endurance volumes may impair power outcomes, with particular need for female-specific research.

title: Discriminating capacities of physical performance testing in male youth soccer academy programmes
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: Objective assessment and monitoring of physical performance in soccer players are mandated features of practice in English soccer academies. Based on these approaches, our interest was to investigate and compare the longitudinal physical performance profiles of those players that had eventually been
sub_theme: talent identification, predictive validity of physical testing
ai_summary: Longitudinal study of 297 youth academy players over 8 years found physical performance tests offered little discriminatory power in predicting which players would reach Premier League or Championship level.

title: The Interactional Accomplishment of Refereeing Decisions in VAR Protocols
journal: Journal of Sport and Social Issues
abstract: This study explores how on-field referees (REF) and Video Assistant Referees (VAR) collaboratively accomplish decision-making during in-match video review sequences in professional football. While VAR was introduced to increase accuracy and reduce error, discrepancies between the VAR's recommendatio
sub_theme: VAR decision-making, referee protocol, video technology
ai_summary: An ethnomethodological analysis of 107 VAR review recordings from Turkish Premier League matches revealed that despite shared video evidence, referees and VARs interpret incidents differently due to divergent professional vision and epistemic stances, challenging assumptions about video technology objectivity.

title: The Untapped Potential of Expert Elicitation in Sports Medicine Epidemiology
abstract: Sports medicine epidemiology has advanced considerably over the past two decades, with standardized surveillance systems and consensus statements improving the quality of data collection and reporting. Yet the field continues to face structural challenges, including small cohorts, heterogeneous samp
sub_theme: expert elicitation in epidemiology
ai_summary: This commentary introduces expert elicitation (SHELF framework) as a structured methodology to formalize clinical judgment into quantitative priors for Bayesian analyses in sports medicine epidemiology, particularly for small cohorts, rare events, and underpowered trials.

title: The musculoskeletal health of retired elite women footballers
abstract: Musculoskeletal complaints, especially knee-related issues, are common among retired elite women's footballers, and are associated with severe injuries during a player's career. Collaborative injury prevention efforts are likely to lead to positive health benefits for current, future and former elit
sub_theme: musculoskeletal injuries in retired elite women footballers
ai_summary: Retired elite women footballers commonly experience musculoskeletal complaints, particularly knee-related issues linked to severe injuries sustained during their playing careers.

title: Targeting Stress Mindset and Irrational Beliefs to Improve Performance and Reduce Anxiety and Depression Symptoms in Academy Athletes
abstract: This study aimed to investigate whether a multimodal cognitive behavioural intervention could enhance academy athletes’ stress mindset, self-compassion, and performance, as well as reduce irrational beliefs and symptoms of anxiety and depression. We delivered 6 × 1 h group workshops at five differen
sub_theme: stress mindset, cognitive behavioral intervention, anxiety, depression
ai_summary: A 6-session multimodal cognitive behavioral intervention in football and rugby academy athletes (n=67) significantly increased stress mindset and self-compassion while reducing irrational beliefs, anxiety, and depression symptoms with small effect sizes.

title: Training adolescent female athletes: Supports, barriers and practical coaching considerations
abstract: The disparity in provision, access and continuation in sport between males and females is evident from childhood. Females undergo significant physical and psychological changes during puberty, which can affect both physical performance and engagement in sports. Strength and conditioning (S&C) coache
sub_theme: female adolescent athlete development, strength and conditioning coaching
ai_summary: Review article presents a coaching framework for adolescent female athletes that considers physiological development, environmental factors, and holistic coaching delivery to support continuation and success in sport at all levels.

title: Multifocal transcranial direct current stimulation enhances lower limb jump performance and neuromuscular adaptation in female collegiate basketball players
abstract: Background Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) has been reported to enhance explosive strength in lower limb skeletal muscles. Nevertheless, findings regarding the impact of tDCS on jump performance remain inconclusive, potentially due to variations in stimulation montage and current inte
sub_theme: transcranial direct current stimulation, jump performance, neuromuscular adaptation
ai_summary: Multifocal anodal tDCS at 4 mA significantly enhanced jump height, concentric impulse, relative peak force and power, and reactive strength index in female collegiate basketball players, without altering lower limb EMG activation patterns.

title: Evaluating training load self-monitoring in female soccer players: Estimating GPS-derived parameters
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: This study explores the feasibility of assessing self-monitoring abilities in a female semi-professional soccer team. It investigates whether athletes can accurately evaluate their external workload by comparing GPS-derived metrics with subjective estimates, including perceived exertion and self-est
sub_theme: training load monitoring, GPS-derived metrics, self-monitoring, external workload
ai_summary: Female semi-professional soccer players consistently underestimated distance covered during training, but regular session-by-session GPS feedback significantly improved their distance estimation accuracy compared to sporadic feedback.

title: Exercise Intensity Modulates the Validity of Non-Linear Heart Rate Time Series Analysis Window Length: Implications for DFAa1 Monitoring
abstract: Abstract Purpose Detrended fluctuation analysis alpha-1 (DFAa1) has emerged as a promising non-invasive biomarker for exercise intensity assessment. However, the standard 2-min analysis window lacks temporal resolution necessary for real-time training applications. This study systematically investig
sub_theme: heart rate variability monitoring, detrended fluctuation analysis
ai_summary: Study demonstrates that DFAa1 window validity for real-time heart rate monitoring in cyclists depends on exercise intensity, with shorter 30-s and 1-min windows providing acceptable validity during high-intensity but not low-intensity exercise.

title: How Data Analytics Has Transformed Player Selection in Franchise Cricket: Evidence from the IPL
abstract: This paper examines how data analytics has reshaped player selection in franchise cricket, using the Indian Premier League (IPL) as a primary setting from 2015 to the present. Drawing on secondary research, the study synthesizes evidence on how franchises have shifted from reputation- and intuition-
sub_theme: data-driven recruitment and auction strategy in IPL franchise cricket
ai_summary: Narrative review of how data analytics transformed player selection in Indian Premier League cricket through ball-by-ball data, matchup profiling, and auction optimization from 2015-present.

title: Wearable Biosensing and Machine Learning for Data-Driven Training and Coaching Support
abstract: Background: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are increasingly integrated into sport and exercise through wearable biosensing systems that enable continuous monitoring and data-driven training adaptation. However, their practical value for coaching depends on the validity of bio
sub_theme: wearable biosensors, AI-driven training adaptation, workload monitoring
ai_summary: Narrative review and evidence map of wearable biosensing and machine learning for adaptive training in endurance, strength, and team sports, highlighting reliable physiological monitoring with practical limitations in field settings.

title: Lower-Limb Biomechanical Adaptations to Exercise-Induced Fatigue During Running: A Systematic Review of Injury-Relevant Mechanical Changes
abstract: Background/Objectives: Exercise-induced fatigue is a fundamental component of running performance and training, yet it is also implicated in altered movement mechanics and increased injury risk. While numerous studies have examined fatigue-related biomechanical changes during running, findings remai
sub_theme: fatigue-related biomechanical changes in running injury risk
ai_summary: Systematic review of 24 studies on running reveals that exercise-induced fatigue consistently alters lower-limb biomechanics, increasing ground contact time, reducing ankle power, and elevating injury-relevant impact loading.

title: Tennis in the heat: a panel discussion
journal: South African Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Tennis is played globally across diverse climates and surfaces, exposing athletes to variable levels of environmental heat stress. With rising global temperatures and more frequent heat events, protecting players’ health has become a major priority in the sport. This panel discussion aimed to synthe
sub_theme: heat stress management, environmental heat illness prevention, cooling strategies
ai_summary: Panel discussion synthesizing evidence on heat stress measurement, management, and mitigation in tennis, highlighting limitations of WBGT indices, evidence-based cooling strategies, and need for harmonized heat policies across player groups and governing bodies.

title: Heavy menstrual bleeding and iron-deficiency anemia in physically active women
abstract: Purpose: Heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) is common in reproductive-age women and may be underreported in sport, where fatigue is often attributed to training load, stress, or low energy availability. This narrative review summarizes evidence on HMB coexisting with iron deficiency (ID) and iron-defici
sub_theme: heavy menstrual bleeding, iron deficiency anemia, female athletes
ai_summary: Narrative review of heavy menstrual bleeding and iron-deficiency anemia in physically active women, proposing integrated screening and management pathway combining routine assessment, laboratory monitoring, nutrition intervention, and timely clinical referral.

title: Spatial Recurrence Is More Common Than Local Recurrence in Youth Athletes With Groin, Anterior Knee, and Heel Pain: A Retrospective Observational Study
abstract: Abstract Objective To determine the incidence and transition patterns of local and spatial recurrence among youth athletes presenting with groin pain (GP), anterior knee pain (AKP), and heel pain (HP). Design Retrospective observational study. Setting Single sports medicine clinic. Participants Yout
sub_theme: recurrence patterns in youth athletes
ai_summary: A retrospective study of 769 clinical episodes in youth athletes found that spatial recurrence (pain transitioning to adjacent body sites) was more common (9.5%) than local recurrence (7.4%) for groin, knee, and heel pain, suggesting whole-body functional assessment is needed for injury prevention.

title: Evaluating models of athlete development through assessment of within- and between-sport and activity variability among competitive female youth soccer athletes
abstract: The balance of primary sport practice and multisport participation during childhood for later success in sport has been debated in models of athlete development. Various mechanisms have been proposed regarding why activity diversity would aid development, including motivation. Here we test this mech
sub_theme: early sport specialization versus diversification and skill development pathways
ai_summary: Survey of 211 female competitive youth soccer athletes (aged 12-19) found higher skill groups participated in more childhood soccer practice and showed less sport diversity but greater team and position diversity, with soccer play hours positively correlated with soccer motivation, supporting early primary-sport engagement models.

title: The Relationship of Ankle Range of Motion and Jump and Agility in Adolescent Basketball Players
journal: The Online Journal of Recreation and Sport
abstract: The ankle joint, which plays a key role in both sagittal and frontal plane movements, contributes substantially to force production during jumping and directional changes in basketball. Limited ankle mobility has been associated with altered biomechanics, reduced performance, and increased injury ri
sub_theme: ankle range of motion and jump and agility performance
ai_summary: Correlational study of 51 adolescent female basketball players found significant negative associations between frontal plane ankle range of motion (inversion, eversion) and jump/agility performance, with greater inversion ROM linked to lower countermovement jump performance (r=−0.343).

title: Sports Commitment and Phubbing: Reflections From Various Sports Disciplines
journal: The Online Journal of Recreation and Sport
abstract: This research aimed to investigate the relationship between sports commitment and phubbing. A total of 477 athletes participated in the study, comprising 220 female and 257 male athletes actively involved in various sports: athletics (n=86), badminton (n=11), basketball (n=62), football (n=101), fut
sub_theme: sports commitment and phubbing behavior
ai_summary: Cross-sectional survey of 477 athletes across 9 sports (athletics, badminton, basketball, football, futsal, handball, table tennis, archery, volleyball) found weak negative correlations between vigor/absorption dimensions of sports commitment and phubbing behaviors (self-isolation, problem awareness, interpersonal conflict).

title: Load-Velocity Profiling in Female Traditional Rowers: Cross-Sectional Associations Between Prone Bench Pull and Half Squat with Rowing Performance
abstract: This study aimed to develop load–velocity (L-V) profiles for prone bench pulls and half squats in elite female traditional rowers, and to assess their association with rowing performance. Eight highly trained female rowers, members of the team that won the Spanish Traditional Rowing Championship, co
sub_theme: load-velocity profiling, velocity-based training
ai_summary: Load-velocity profiling at 30% 1RM in prone bench pull and half squat exercises significantly correlates with rowing ergometer performance in elite female rowers, supporting velocity-based training applications.

title: Factors Associated with Urinary Incontinence in Female Weightlifters
abstract: Background/Objectives: Urinary incontinence (UI) is common among women practicing sports, particularly those involving heavy lifting or high-impact movements that increase intra-abdominal pressure. UI can negatively affect social life, self-confidence, and motivation to remain active. This study aim
sub_theme: urinary incontinence, stress incontinence
ai_summary: Urinary incontinence affects 60.7% of female weightlifters but was not significantly associated with sociodemographic, obstetric, training characteristics, or lifting practices in this cross-sectional survey of 84 athletes.

title: ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT RECONSTRUCTION SURGERY CHANGES THE KINETIC JUMP CHARACTERISTICS IN FEMALE PAEDIATRIC PATIENTS
abstract: Characteristics of jumping kinetics have been extensively studied, serving as a performance metric in various sports and aiding in the assessment of rehabilitation progress following injury and clearance for return to sports. Deficits in jump propulsion have been observed in adults for up to 9 month
sub_theme: ACL reconstruction, return-to-sport, jump kinetics
ai_summary: Female adolescents 5-20 months post-ACL reconstruction surgery showed altered kinetic profiles during countermovement jump compared to non-injured controls, with deficits in ground reaction force and propulsion metrics.

title: Measuring Impulse-DSI and its Derivatives Via the Isometric Belt Squat: Assessing Relationships with Sprint Ability Among Division 1 Team Sport Athletes
journal: International Journal of Strength and Conditioning
abstract: The dynamic strength index (DSI) is a common athlete profiling tool that has traditionally been derived as the ratio between the peak force in the isometric mid-thigh pull (IMTP) and the countermovement jump (CMJ) to identify ballistic strength deficits. Recently, an impulse-based DSI (iDSI) has bee
sub_theme: dynamic strength index, sprint performance, impulse metrics
ai_summary: Impulse-based dynamic strength index derived from isometric belt squat and countermovement jump predicted 40-56% of variance in sprint split times among Division 1 team sport athletes, with reliable measurements (ICC > 0.93).

title: Relationships between countermovement jump-derived variables, eccentric hamstring strength, and agility performance in elite female basketball players
abstract: This study investigated whether agility performance in elite female basketball players could be predicted from countermovement jump (CMJ) force–plate metrics, eccentric hamstring strength, and anthropometric characteristics. Forty-five athletes competing in Iceland’s top division completed assessmen
sub_theme: agility, reactive agility, jump kinetics, hamstring strength
ai_summary: In elite female basketball players, countermovement jump kinetics and eccentric hamstring strength did not individually predict agility performance (R² = 0.959 but no individual significance), indicating agility is a distinct neuromuscular quality influenced by perceptual-cognitive factors.

title: Ballistic power: GPS-derived measurements suitable for the real-time monitoring of neuromuscular fatigue during repeated sprints
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: Power-force-velocity ( <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline" overflow="scroll"> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mi>v</mml:mi> </mml:math> ) measurements have traditionally been employed to characterize the limits of an athlete’s neuromuscular system. Ho
sub_theme: neuromuscular fatigue monitoring, repeated sprint ability, ballistic power
ai_summary: Novel ballistic power and force-velocity offset metrics derived from GPS tracking effectively monitored neuromuscular fatigue during repeated sprint ability testing in 24 physically active males.

title: Optimizing triple jump performance and knee biomechanics in junior figure skaters: a longitudinal evaluation of rotational harness training in Kazakhstan
abstract: Introduction: Triple jumps are essential for competitive progression in junior figure skating but impose high mechanical loads on the knee, increasing the risk of overuse injuries. This study evaluated the long-term effects of rotational harness training on landing biomechanics, technical progressio
sub_theme: rotational harness training and triple jump biomechanics
ai_summary: Longitudinal 36-month study of 28 female junior figure skaters found that rotational harness training reduced peak ground reaction forces (5.6 vs 7.3 × body weight), increased knee flexion, and accelerated triple-jump mastery while reducing knee pathology incidence and improving psychological confidence.

title: Exploratory Factor Analyses of the Female and Male Body Checking Questionnaires in Collegiate Athletes
abstract: Introduction: Collegiate athletes have demonstrated heightened risk for disordered eating and body image concerns, yet many body checking questionnaires have been developed and validated in clinical and non-clinical adult populations which reflects a gap in measures for the athlete population. Metho
sub_theme: body checking and body image in collegiate athletes
ai_summary: Exploratory factor analysis of 174 collegiate athletes (86 female, 84 male) validated reduced-item versions of the Body Checking Questionnaire (12 items, two factors) and Male Body Checking Questionnaire (11 items, three factors) with high internal consistency for athlete populations.

title: The Impact of Coaching Leadership Style on Motivation and Team Cohesion in Volleyball
journal: Proceedings of The International Conference on Future of Teaching and Education
abstract: This study examines the relationship between coaching leadership style, athlete motivation, and team cohesion in volleyball. The research was conducted with 28 female players from a local volleyball club in Shkodër, Albania, aged between 16 and 25 years. A mixed-methods design was employed, combinin
sub_theme: leadership style effects on motivation and team cohesion
ai_summary: Mixed-methods study of 28 female Albanian volleyball players (aged 16-25) found democratic and transformational coaching leadership styles associated with higher intrinsic motivation, athlete satisfaction, and team cohesion, while autocratic styles reduced commitment and social bonds.

title: Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (REDs) and site-specific bone mineral density in female adolescent artistic athletes
abstract: REDs negatively impacts bone mineral density (BMD), menstruation, growth, and maturation. The prevalence of REDs indicators in artistic adolescent athletes is unknown. The primary objective of this study was to examine the prevalence and factors associated with REDs in female adolescent artistic ath
sub_theme: Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport and bone mineral density in adolescent female artistic athletes
ai_summary: Cross-sectional study of 74 female adolescent artistic athletes (artistic swimmers, dancers, figure skaters) aged 9-19 found 45.9% had ≥1 Relative Energy Deficiency indicator, with higher BMD in dancers and figure skaters relative to artistic swimmers, emphasizing need for RED screening in artistic sports.

title: Metabolic Bone Disease in Athletes
abstract: Abstract Metabolic bone disease is characterized by impaired bone strength, density, or mineralization, increasingly observed in athletes due to complex nutritional, hormonal, and mechanical factors. The underlying pathophysiology includes dysregulated bone turnover driven by hormonal imbalances, in
sub_theme: metabolic bone disease in athletes
ai_summary: Narrative review of metabolic bone disease in athletes identifies dysregulated bone turnover from hormonal imbalances and training excess as key mechanisms, with female athletes with menstrual irregularities and energy deficits at particular risk for osteoporosis, and recommends nutritional optimization and bone screening.

title: The Impact of Isometric and Isotonic Exercises on the Reduction of Shoulder Muscle Injuries in Volleyball Players
journal: Proceedings of The International Conference on Future of Teaching and Education
abstract: Shoulder injuries are among the most frequent musculoskeletal problems in volleyball, often resulting from repetitive overhead movements and inadequate stabilization of the shoulder complex. Preventive exercise programs are therefore essential to reduce injury risk and maintain performance. The pres
sub_theme: shoulder injury prevention, isometric vs isotonic training
ai_summary: Randomized trial comparing isometric and isotonic shoulder conditioning programs in university volleyball players found isometric training reduced injury incidence by 58% compared to 46% for isotonic training.

title: From Injury to Impact: Optimizing Return-to-Play Outcomes and Reinjury Prevention via Four-Pillar Rehabilitation Strategy in Elite Football—A Clinical Study in a Sports Scenario
abstract: Objectives: This clinical commentary presents a four-pillar rehabilitation framework implemented in the elite football setting of OFI Crete FC and designed to facilitate the return of football players to training and competitive play. The framework is structured around five core components: (a) effe
sub_theme: return-to-play, load management, reinjury prevention
ai_summary: Three-year observational clinical study of OFI Crete FC implementing a four-pillar rehabilitation framework achieved 60% reduction in injury rates and 10% reinjury rate across 87 elite players.

title: Pitfalls and How to Avoid Misdiagnosis in Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the Ankle and Foot in Athletes
abstract: Abstract Magnetic resonance imaging is a vital tool in sports medicine for evaluating ankle and foot injuries in athletes, offering detailed insights into bone, cartilage, ligament, and tendon pathology. However, the findings in athletes, especially those who are asymptomatic, can present pitfalls t
sub_theme: MRI interpretation, ankle and foot imaging in athletes
ai_summary: Narrative review of magnetic resonance imaging pitfalls in ankle and foot evaluation emphasizes importance of correlating imaging findings with clinical assessment to avoid overtreatment and support safe return to play in athletes.

title: Physical Match Performance of Professional Men’s Football Players from Different Competitive Levels During Direct Competition
abstract: The influence of competitive standards on physical performance in professional football remains controversial, particularly when teams from different divisions compete against each other. This study aimed to analyze position-specific differences in physical performance, both in possession and out of
sub_theme: position-specific physical performance, competitive level differences
ai_summary: Analysis of Copa del Rey matches using multi-camera tracking showed First Division players covered greater distances in possession while Second Division players performed higher distances out of possession, with differences modulated by playing position and tactical roles.

title: AI-assisted and Big-Unit teaching enhance speed-skating performance through psychological mechanisms in adolescents: evidence from a three-arm intervention study
abstract: Background Innovative instructional approaches are increasingly advocated in physical education to enhance both motor skill development and psychological adaptation. However, few studies have directly compared micro-level (AI-assisted) and macro-level (Big-Unit) teaching models, or examined the psyc
sub_theme: AI-assisted teaching, skill learning in adolescents
ai_summary: AI-assisted and Big-Unit teaching models significantly improved 500-m skating performance and psychological outcomes (motivation, self-efficacy, resilience) in adolescent speed skaters compared to conventional instruction over 8 weeks.

title: The Relationship Between Agility Score and Ankle Flexibility and the Risk of Ankle Injury Among Basketball Players at Giovanni Catholic Senior High School Kupang
journal: International Journal of Current Science Research and Review
abstract: Background: Ankle injuries are the most common type of injury experienced by basketball players, mainly due to pressure or rapid twisting forces upon landing after jumping. Agility scores and ankle flexibility are frequently associated with ankle injury risk, however research focused on high school
sub_theme: ankle injury risk factors in high school basketball
ai_summary: Cross-sectional study of 43 high school basketball players found no significant correlation between agility score or ankle flexibility and ankle injury risk using Spearman rank correlation.

title: The Relationship Between Agility Score and Ankle Flexibility and the Risk of Ankle Injury Among Basketball Players at Giovanni Catholic Senior High School Kupang

journal: Zenodo (CERN European Organization for Nuclear Research)
abstract: Abstract : Background: Ankle injuries are the most common type of injury experienced by basketball players, mainly due to pressure or rapid twisting forces upon landing after jumping. Agility scores and ankle flexibility are frequently associated with ankle injury risk, however research focused on h

ai_summary: A cross-sectional study of 43 high school basketball players found no significant relationship between agility scores or ankle flexibility and ankle injury risk, measured via the Foot and Ankle Outcome Score.

title: NSAID Use Is Not Associated With Persisting Symptoms in Adolescent Concussion
abstract: Objective: To investigate the relationship between injury factors, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medication (NSAID) use, and concussion outcomes. Design: Prospective cohort. Participants: Adolescents (N = 118) ≤14 days of concussion seen at a sports medicine center between November 2020 and May 202
sub_theme: concussion recovery, NSAID use in adolescents
ai_summary: Prospective cohort study of 118 adolescent concussion patients finding that while NSAID use was associated with more severe initial symptoms, it was not associated with persisting post-concussion symptoms at 28+ days.

title: Cross Bracing Protocol for Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Rupture Has Unacceptably High Failure Rate Relative to Surgical Stabilization: A 2-year Controlled Cohort Study
abstract: Objective: To compare the clinical outcome of patients electing to undergo the Cross Bracing Protocol (CBP) for ACL rupture with those choosing surgical stabilization. Design: Observational prospective cohort study with 2-year follow-up. Setting: Private subspecialist sports orthopedics and sports m
sub_theme: ACL rupture, cross-bracing vs surgical stabilization
ai_summary: Two-year prospective cohort study comparing cross-bracing protocol to surgical ACL reconstruction in 80 athletes, showing the non-surgical protocol had unacceptably high failure rates (70% recurrent instability vs 2.5% with surgery) in pivoting sports participants.

title: Relationship Between Sport Specialization and Short-Term Health-Related Quality of Life in Youth Athletes After Injury
abstract: Background: Researchers have examined associations between sport specialization and injury. However, no studies have investigated associations between sport specialization and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) after injury. Hypothesis: Among injured youth athletes, level of sport specialization
sub_theme: sport specialization, health-related quality of life after injury, sex differences
ai_summary: Cross-sectional study of 336 injured youth athletes (8-18 years) finding no association between sport specialization level and short-term health-related quality of life post-injury, but female athletes reported worse HRQoL scores than males across pain, depression, and anxiety measures.

title: The Anatomy of Excellence: A Multidimensional Analysis of Physiological and Performance Determinants Distinguishing Elite from Sub-Elite Handball Players
journal: International Journal of Multidisciplinary Research in Science, Engineering and Technology.
abstract: ABSTRACT: Handball is a complex, intermittent team sport demanding a unique blend of anthropometric, physiological, technical, and cognitive attributes. While talent identification programs often focus on isolated metrics, the precise multidimensional profile that separates elite (international/nati
sub_theme: talent identification, elite vs sub-elite discrimination, multidimensional profiling
ai_summary: Cross-sectional study of 60 male handball players comparing elite and sub-elite players across anthropometry, physiology, sport-specific performance, and cognitive skills, with discriminant analysis identifying four variables that correctly classified 93.3% of players by elite status.

title: Association Between Functional Muscle Assessment and Psychological Factors on Return to Sport and Graft Failure After ACL Reconstruction
abstract: Background: Few researchers have examined both psychological and physical factors simultaneously in return to sport (RTS) and reinjury. Purpose: To assess the role of psychological profiles and physical aspects in RTS and reinjury risk and to inform and develop innovative treatment strategies that m
sub_theme: psychological profiles and ACL reinjury risk, return to sport
ai_summary: Psychological profiles combined with muscle strength assessment predicted ACL return-to-sport outcomes; athletes with high confidence and low anxiety achieved 77.8% RTS rate versus 45.8% in high-anxiety/depressive profiles, with females overrepresented in negative profiles.

title: PREVALENCE OF T-WAVE INVERSION IN FEMALE ATHLETES COMPARED TO MALES
abstract: https://youtu.be/8O1PWHlLtH4 BACKGROUND: Electrocardiogram (ECG) screening is widely used in sports medicine to identify athletes at risk of sudden cardiac arrest or death (SCA/D). Abnormal ECGs are reported more frequently in females over the age of 16, often driven by T-wave inversion (TWI) in lea
sub_theme: sex differences in ECG findings, T-wave inversion in young athletes
ai_summary: Female high school athletes showed higher prevalence of isolated T-wave inversion in leads V1–V3 (OR 2.15) compared with males; abnormal ECGs were rare (2%) and none of the female TWI cases were associated with sudden cardiac death risk.

title: All-Inside and All-Knotless Soft Tissue Anchor Repair for Chronic Lateral Ankle Instability: A Retrospective Study of a New Surgical Technique
abstract: Background: Chronic lateral ankle instability (CLAI) is a common pathology among athletes. Although the open modified Broström-Gould procedure remains the gold standard, arthroscopic approaches have gained popularity due to their minimally invasive nature and promising outcomes. Despite growing clin
sub_theme: ankle ligament repair outcomes
ai_summary: Retrospective study of 36 athletes (64% male) undergoing arthroscopic knotless anchor repair for chronic lateral ankle instability showed excellent outcomes with AOFAS scores improving from 61 to 96 at 12 months, with 91.7% patient satisfaction.

title: Basketball Training Movement Pattern Recognition and Personalized Teaching Strategy Design Based on Multidimensional Data Analysis
journal: International Journal of Computer Information Systems and Industrial Management Applications
abstract: Basketball is a sport with a broad grassroots following, and its scientific research value has also garnered significant attention. Currently, most basketball training content is based on coaches' experience and intuition when training athletes, lacking unified standards and personalized guidance. T
sub_theme: movement pattern recognition, personalized training optimization
ai_summary: Integrated dual-stream CNN-LSTM model with motion trajectory tracking and knowledge graphs to identify basketball training movement patterns and generate personalized technical improvement recommendations for players.

title: The silent few: An ethnographic study of gender perceptions in the Syracuse University esports community
abstract: Abstract As Syracuse University's esports players continue to strive for greater notoriety and national collegiate representation through the new multi‐million dollar 3‐track academic esports program launched in August 2024, the underrepresentation of women in collegiate and professional esports spa
sub_theme: gender discrimination, toxic male culture, in-game communication
ai_summary: Ethnographic study of Syracuse University esports community revealed persistent gender inequity through toxic in-game communication ('comms'), male homosocial dynamics, and normalization of discriminatory behaviors that exclude women gamers.

title: Mind‐Muscle‐Environment Interactions: Psychophysiological Determinants of Optimal Pacing in Olympic Winter Endurance Sports
journal: Scandinavian Journal of Medicine and Science in Sports
abstract: ABSTRACT Pacing is a critical determinant of performance in Olympic endurance winter sports such as cross‐country skiing, biathlon, and speed skating. Although the physiological (“engine”) and psychological (“operator”) determinants of pacing have frequently been examined in isolation, growing evide
sub_theme: pacing strategy, psychophysiological mechanisms
ai_summary: A narrative review of Olympic winter endurance sports (cross-country skiing, biathlon, speed skating) proposes an integrated psychophysiological framework for understanding pacing as driven by mind-muscle-environment interactions.

title: The transformation of football clubs from social associations to commercial organizations
abstract: Aim. This work aimed to identify the key stages and factors in the transition of football clubs from social associations to commercial organizations. Objectives. The study seeks to analyze the historical and legal prerequisites for the transformation of football clubs; to systematize organizational
sub_theme: organizational transformation, commercialization history
ai_summary: A historical-analytical study identified key stages in the transformation of football clubs from social associations to commercial organizations, driven by legalization of professional status, media deregulation, and global commercial impulses across England, Italy, and Spain.

title: From Sprint to Marathon: Physiological Adaptation of a Professional Dancer to Long-Term Theatrical Contracts
journal: The American Journal of Interdisciplinary Innovations and Research
abstract: The study is oriented toward an integrated comprehension of the physiological, biomechanical, and psychoemotional determinants of a dancer’s professional transformation during the transition from the domain of competitive ballroom dancing to the entertainment-show format on ocean cruise liners. The
sub_theme: aerobic-anaerobic transition, adaptation to sustained performance, relative energy deficiency in sport
ai_summary: Case study of a professional ballroom dancer's physiological adaptation during transition from competitive dance to sustained theatrical performance on ocean liners, revealing ankle-to-knee injury redistribution and relative energy deficiency risk under prolonged contract cycles.

title: The Sport Publication Observational Research Tool (SPORT): An Objective Tool to Score the Methodological Quality of Observational Clinical Sports Medicine Research
abstract: Background: A critical component of conducting systematic reviews or meta-analyses is assessing the methodological quality and bias of included studies. Several methodological quality assessment tools have been developed; however, these tools may not be relevant to observational sports medicine rese
sub_theme: methodological quality assessment tool for observational sports medicine research
ai_summary: Development and validation of the Sport Publication Observational Research Tool (SPORT), a 19-item consensus-based assessment instrument for evaluating methodological quality and bias in observational sports medicine studies.

title: Comparison of Physical Fitness of Elite Female Soccer Players According to Their Playing Positions
journal: Journal of Basic and Clinical Health Sciences
abstract: Purpose: Although many studies have fully explained the fitness requirements of male soccer players in respect to their respective in-field positions, today a lack of studies that focus attention on the women's aspect still exists. Therefore, this study focused on assessing and comparing the physica
sub_theme: positional fitness differences
ai_summary: Comparative analysis of 19 elite female soccer players' physical fitness across positions (forwards, midfielders, defenders) found no significant differences in anthropometric or physical parameters, suggesting modern soccer training produces well-rounded players.

title: Agreement and Reliability Between Urine Reagent Strips and Refractometry for Field Assessment of Hydration in Ultra-Trail Runners
abstract: Background/Objectives: Accurate hydration assessment is critical for optimizing performance and preventing heat-related complications in ultra-endurance athletes. This study evaluated the agreement and reliability between urine reagent strips and refractometry for field-based hydration assessment vi
sub_theme: hydration assessment in ultra-endurance athletes
ai_summary: Urine reagent strips and refractometry demonstrated strong agreement (r=0.92-0.99) for field-based hydration assessment in ultra-trail runners, with both methods detecting significant exercise-induced hypohydration across 241-km multi-stage events.

title: The Effect of Small-Sided Games Training on the Short Passing Ability of Bhanu Football Academy Players Aged 13–15 Years in Mukomuko
journal: Indonesian Journal of Sport Health and Physical Education Science
abstract: Background: Short passing ability is a fundamental skill in football, particularly for youth players. sub_theme: technical skill training, short passing ability, small-sided games
ai_summary: A pre-post experimental study of 30 youth football players aged 13–15 years found that 6 weeks of small-sided games training significantly improved short passing ability by 35.4%, as measured by the Johnson Soccer Test.

title: Current Concepts in Hip and Core Assessment to Reduce the Risk of ACL Injury
journal: International Journal of Sports Physical Therapy
abstract: Background Hip and trunk (“core”) muscle dysfunction has emerged as a modifiable contributor to lower-limb biomechanics linked with non-contact anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries.
