abstract: Abstract Altitude training enhances haematological adaptations and endurance at sea level, typically requiring exposure to ∼2500 m altitude for 3–4 weeks. Emerging evidence suggests that low‐dose carbon monoxide (CO) inhalation might mimic hypoxia and might be used by elite athletes. In this study,
sub_theme: altitude training simulation, carbon monoxide exposure, haematological adaptation
ai_summary: A randomized crossover study of 8 well-trained endurance athletes (4 males, 4 females) found that 4 weeks of low-dose carbon monoxide inhalation at sea level significantly increased hemoglobin mass (+53.6 g), red blood cell volume (+156.6 mL), and blood volume (+240.4 mL) compared to ambient air, simulating live-high, train-low effects without improving muscle oxidative capacity or performance.

title: Allergy-compatible symptoms among federated swimmers in Portugal: a cross-sectional study using the AQUA® questionnaire
abstract: Swimmers are chronically exposed to water disinfection by-products (commonly from chlorination) and to indoor air conditions that may aggravate allergic and respiratory symptoms. Evidence is robust for elite cohorts, but competitive swimmers outside Olympic settings remain understudied. We conducted
sub_theme: allergy-compatible symptoms, chlorine exposure, indoor air quality
ai_summary: A cross-sectional study of 95 Portuguese competitive swimmers found 81.1% screened positive for allergy-compatible symptoms using the AQUA questionnaire, with upper airway complaints most frequent (63.2% nasal obstruction), higher prevalence in women (88.7% vs. 71.4%), and associations with younger age, ≥7 weekly training sessions, and pool temperature >25°C.

title: Association between sleep quality and psychological wellbeing in 175 elite adult athletes: a cross-sectional study
abstract: Purpose This study examined the relationship between sleep quality and mood state and identified psychological predictors of sleep disturbance in elite adult athletes. Methods A stratified cluster sample of 175 elite adult athletes (67 males, 108 females; age 22.6 ± 3.7 yr) was recruited from Sichua
sub_theme: sleep quality, mood disturbance, fatigue, gender differences
ai_summary: A cross-sectional study of 175 elite athletes (67 males, 108 females) from China found sleep disturbance was independently predicted by fatigue and total mood disturbance (explaining 57% of variance), with the mood-sleep correlation significantly stronger in female athletes than males, and depression scores higher in disturbed-sleep females.

title: Loaded Single-Leg Roman Chair Hold Preferentially Increases Biceps Femoris Activation, Whereas the Nordic Hamstring Exercise Emphasises Semitendinosus Activation in Professional Athletes
abstract: Background and Objectives: Hamstring strain injuries (HSIs) are frequent and recurrent in athletes who perform high-speed running. The long head of the biceps femoris (BFlh) is often affected by HSIs. While the Nordic hamstring exercise (NHE) is used for prevention, evidence shows it mainly activate
sub_theme: hamstring activation, Nordic hamstring exercise vs. Roman Chair Hold, electromyography
ai_summary: A comparative study of 36 professional handball players (17 females, 19 males) using electromyography found the single-leg Roman Chair Hold with progressive loading (up to +20 kg) preferentially activated the biceps femoris long head (72.9% MVIC) compared to the Nordic hamstring exercise (46.5%), while the Nordic exercise emphasized semitendinosus activation, suggesting differential effectiveness for preventing hamstring injuries.

title: Evaluating Takeoff Mechanics Between Dancers and Non-Dancers During Bilateral Jumps
abstract: Many athletes in sports that consist of movements with sharp turns, such as women's basketball and soccer, experience a high amount of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries in proportion to dancers, who experience low rates of ACL injuries. There has been minimal research on how jump takeoff mec
sub_theme: ACL injury risk, jump takeoff mechanics, dancers vs. non-dancers
ai_summary: A biomechanical study comparing 10 female dancers and 9 active non-dancers found no significant differences in peak vertical ground reaction force, jump height, or lower extremity joint angles/moments during bilateral squat jumps, suggesting jump mechanics alone do not explain the lower ACL injury rates observed in dancers compared to basketball and soccer athletes.

title: No Significant Difference in Return-to-Sport Rates Between Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction With Lateral Extra-Articular Tenodesis and Isolated Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
journal: The American Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Background: Although anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction (ACLR) remains the standard to treat ACL ruptures, athletes remain at higher risk of graft rerupture. Concomitant lateral extra-articular tenodesis (LET) has gained popularity by improving rotatory stability, yet no synthesis of ex
sub_theme: ACL reconstruction, return-to-sport
ai_summary: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 14 studies (1791 athletes across multiple sports) found no significant difference in return-to-sport rates between isolated ACL reconstruction and ACL reconstruction with lateral extra-articular tenodesis (88.2% both groups).

title: Does Timing of Concussion in Season Affect Incidence and Recovery in Division I Collegiate Football Players? A CARE Consortium Study
abstract: Objective: To investigate whether seasonality is associated with (1) concussion incidence and (2) recovery outcomes, including the time to symptom resolution (SR) and return-to-play (RTP) in Division I college football players. Setting: Multi-institution study using the CARE Consortium database comp
sub_theme: concussion, seasonality, return-to-play
ai_summary: Prospective cohort study of 682 Division I college football players found preseason concussions had highest incidence (4.73 per 100 players) and faster symptom resolution compared to early and late-season concussions, with no difference in return-to-play timing.

title: Prediction of Collegiate Pitching Performance from Longitudinal Neuromuscular Performance Testing Data
abstract: BACKGROUND: Objective performance testing has become central to baseball, offering insights into force production, neuromuscular readiness, and joint-specific strength that are often invisible through observation. Despite advances in pitch tracking, no study has examined the relationship between the
sub_theme: neuromuscular testing and pitching performance prediction
ai_summary: Multivariate linear regression model explains 61.5% of variance in collegiate pitching Stuff+ using grip strength, eccentric rate of force development, and shoulder/hip strength metrics.

title: Focused Attention Meditation as a Pre-Exercise Strategy for Reducing Anxiety in Speed Skaters
abstract: Anxiety is a common psychological challenge among athletes, particularly in response to intense training sessions. This randomized crossover study investigated the immediate effects of a single session of focused attention meditation on anxiety, autonomic responses, and performance during high-inten
sub_theme: anxiety reduction, pre-exercise meditation
ai_summary: A single session of focused attention meditation reduced state anxiety in speed skaters before high-intensity interval training without compromising performance, compared to controlled breathing and random thinking.

title: MARATHON RUNNING IN AN ERA OF RISING TEMPERATURES: ASSESSING THE HEAT-RELATED ILLNESS RISK IN A SIMULATED STUDY
journal: Zenodo (CERN European Organization for Nuclear Research)
abstract: Background: Running a marathon is considered one of the most arduous tests of physical endurance for the human body. Climate change has heightened the risk of heat-related illnesses among marathon runners as global temperatures rise. Aim: This study aimed to investigate gender-specific percentages o
sub_theme: heat-related illness risk, gender differences, climate change, marathon running
ai_summary: A physiological simulation of marathon runners based on demographic data found that female runners face greater risk of heat-related illness than males across all Wet-Bulb Globe Temperature scenarios, with 57.6% of females at risk at 37°C scapular temperature.

title: MARATHON RUNNING IN AN ERA OF RISING TEMPERATURES: ASSESSING THE HEAT-RELATED ILLNESS RISK IN A SIMULATED STUDY
journal: Zenodo (CERN European Organization for Nuclear Research)
abstract: Background: Running a marathon is considered one of the most arduous tests of physical endurance for the human body. Climate change has heightened the risk of heat-related illnesses among marathon runners as global temperatures rise. Aim: This study aimed to investigate gender-specific percentages o
sub_theme: heat-related illness risk, gender differences, climate change, marathon running
ai_summary: A physiological simulation of marathon runners based on demographic data found that female runners face greater risk of heat-related illness than males across all Wet-Bulb Globe Temperature scenarios, with 57.6% of females at risk at 37°C scapular temperature.

title: ЕФЕКТИВНІСТЬ ЗМАГАЛЬНИХ ДІЙ ЖІНОЧИХ БАСКЕТБОЛЬНИХ КОМАНД В ІГРАХ З РІЗНИМИ СУПЕРНИКАМИ
journal: Physical culture sports and health of the nation
abstract: Abstract. Relevance. One of the key directions for improving the high-performance athlete training system is to enhance the effectiveness of training process management by objectifying knowledge regarding the structure of competitive activity. The analysis and generalization of such data, along with
sub_theme: competitive activity analysis, technical-tactical performance, game phases, women's basketball
ai_summary: Analysis of 9 games from Ukrainian Women's Basketball Super League found that player adaptation to competitive conditions occurs in the first 4–6 minutes, performance stabilizes until 12–14 minutes, then deteriorates due to physical/emotional loads, with critical inefficiency periods at quarter boundaries.

title: ОСОБЛИВОСТІ СУЧАСНОЇ ЗМАГАЛЬНОЇ ДІЯЛЬНОСТІ БІГУНІВ НА СЕРЕДНІ ДИСТАНЦІЇ
journal: Physical culture sports and health of the nation
abstract: Abstract. The relevance of the study is determined by the decline in the performance of Ukrainian middle-distance runners and the need to review traditional approaches to their training. Analysis of global training models focused on the development of speed and speed-strength qualities is the basis
sub_theme: middle-distance running training models
ai_summary: Analysis of competitive activity and training approaches in Ukrainian middle-distance runners (800m) reveals that speed abilities, speed endurance, and strength qualities are key success factors, contrasting with traditional Ukrainian emphasis on general endurance.

title: Positional and Temporal Intermittency in Football: A Metabolic Model Approach
abstract: Abstract This study examined positional differences in the intermittent nature of efforts during professional football matches and compared two analytical models: one using a fixed metabolic power threshold (Pmet20) and another based on the relationship between oxygen consumption and metabolic power
sub_theme: metabolic power, positional intermittency, GPS analysis
ai_summary: Analysis of 24 professional football players across 50 matches using GPS technology showed significant positional differences in high and low metabolic load efforts, with the VO2-Pmet method identifying twice longer high metabolic load durations than the fixed Pmet20 threshold.

title: Systematic Review of Exercise Interventions in Archery: Injury Management and Performance Outcomes
abstract: Background. Exercise-based interventions are increasingly incorporated into archery training to enhance performance and reduce injury risk. However, the extent to which these interventions directly contribute to injury management and performance improvement remains unclear. Objectives. This systemat
sub_theme: exercise interventions, archery-specific training
ai_summary: Systematic review of 15 archery studies found that core stability, Pilates-based balance, and strength training produced moderate-to-large improvements in postural stability, muscle strength, and shooting accuracy, with indirect benefits for injury prevention.

title: Musculoskeletal injuries in women aerial acrobatics sports
abstract: Background Despite the growing popularity of aerial sports, limited research has investigated musculoskeletal (MSK) injury incidence among female acrobatic athletes. Understanding injury prevalence is essential for implementing effective prevention strategies. Objective To investigate demographic ch
sub_theme: injury incidence, female aerial acrobatics, musculoskeletal injury prevalence
ai_summary: A cross-sectional survey of 60 female aerial acrobatics athletes in Saudi Arabia found 20% current injury prevalence with back, knee, and wrist as most common injury sites.

title: A novel approach to monitoring selective fatigue in female softball athletes: evaluating load-velocity relationship variables and specific performance metrics
abstract: Introduction The purpose of this study was to assess whether bench press load-velocity (L-V) relationship variables serving as indicators of maximal theoretical force capacity ( L 0 ), maximal theoretical velocity capacity ( v 0 ), and maximal theoretical power capacity (A line ), as well as the sof
sub_theme: fatigue monitoring, load-velocity relationships, softball-specific metrics
ai_summary: Load-velocity relationship variables and softball-specific performance metrics (hit/throw distance) showed moderate sensitivity to fatigue in 12 female professional softball players but were less sensitive than blood lactate and RPE.

title: The Effect of Educational Intervention on Legal Anti-Doping Knowledge and Doping Tendency in Elite Athletes
abstract: Studies have rarely examined the effects of changes in legal anti-doping knowledge (LADK) on doping tendencies in athletes. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a structured educational intervention focused on LADK and to analyze how LADK changes affect elite athletes’ doping tendency.
sub_theme: anti-doping education, doping tendency, legal anti-doping knowledge
ai_summary: A structured educational intervention significantly improved legal anti-doping knowledge in 140 elite athletes (50% female) across individual and team sports, but logistic regression found no significant correlation between knowledge gains and reduced doping tendency.

title: The nutritional environment and food access of female athletes at HBCUs: a qualitative analysis
abstract: Purpose Female student-athletes attending Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) may encounter distinct challenges related to food access, particularly when their campuses are situated in areas with limited food availability. This study assessed food security (FS) and explored the live
sub_theme: food security, female student-athletes, HBCUs, nutritional access
ai_summary: Qualitative interviews with 10 HBCU female student-athletes revealed evenly split food security status and identified barriers to adequate nutrition including limited cooking resources, inconsistent cafeteria offerings, and time constraints.

title: Multi-factorial profiling of athletes integrating personality, psychological skills, and Psychophysiological performance indicators
abstract: Abstract Sports performance is shaped by the interaction of various factors, including the athlete’s personality, psychological skills and psychophysiological performance. The aim of this study was to develop a multi-factorial profile of athletes, combining personality traits, psychological skills a
sub_theme: multi-factorial athlete profiling, personality, psychological skills, psychophysiological performance
ai_summary: Multivariate and cluster analysis of 304 athletes identified four distinct multi-factorial profiles combining personality traits, psychological skills, and psychophysiological performance indicators (reaction time, stress tolerance, impulsivity) that differed by sport type and competitive level.

title: Footwear-Induced Differences in Biomechanics and Perceived Comfort During Unanticipated Side-Step Cutting: An Exploratory Study in Female Football Players
abstract: Cleated footwear in football increasingly incorporates sex-specific design features intended to address a clear gap in anthropometric and biomechanical differences in female athletes. However, experimental evidence evaluating how these designs may influence lower-extremity biomechanics during sport
sub_theme: footwear design, female football, lower-extremity biomechanics, cutting
ai_summary: A pilot study of 20 female football players found that female-specific prototype cleats reduced ankle inversion angles and moments during side-step cutting compared to standard cleats, but participants rated standard cleats as more comfortable.

title: A periodized winter training block enhances anaerobic capacity in elite female rowers during 30-second maximal rowing
abstract: Objective In competitive rowing, the winter training phase is a conventional periodized block focused on foundational physiological development through land-based strength and power training. The primary aim of this phase is to enhance athletes’ force-generating capabilities and metabolic resilience
sub_theme: anaerobic capacity, periodized training, winter training block
ai_summary: A 16-week periodized winter training block in 5 elite female rowers significantly improved anaerobic capacity during a 30-second rowing test, increasing mean power output by 14.1% and anaerobic energy contribution by 22.0% while maintaining VO2max.

title: Anorexic Readiness Syndrome in Women Engaging in Body-Shaping Exercise
abstract: Background: Eating disorders are increasingly diagnosed in young women, particularly during adolescence. The recently described Anorexic Readiness Syndrome (ARS) is more common than full-blown anorexia. It has been identified in female athletes engaging in disciplines focusing on the aesthetics of t
sub_theme: eating disorders, anorexic readiness syndrome, body-shaping exercise
ai_summary: A survey of 659 women engaging in body-shaping physical activity found that over 96% showed medium or high levels of Anorexic Readiness Syndrome, with significant correlations between ARS frequency, exercise intensity, and menstrual irregularities.

title: Integrated Training Program for Rugby Sevens: A Multivariate Approach of Motor, Functional, and Metabolic Components
abstract: Purpose: This study assessed the adaptations resulting from implementing an experimental, integrated training program tailored to sex-specific traits. The aim was to enhance motor abilities, aerobic capacity, and metabolic variables in female and male rugby sevens athletes. Methods: Employing a comb
sub_theme: integrated training, sex-specific adaptations, motor and metabolic components
ai_summary: A 12-week integrated training program in 24 elite rugby sevens athletes (12 female, 12 male) showed significant improvements across sprint, jump, aerobic capacity, and metabolic measures, with sex-specific differences where females improved more in aerobic capacity and males in explosive power.

title: Integrated Mechanical and Cardiopulmonary Adaptations During Repeated Jumps in Volleyball Players: Insights from CPET Analysis
abstract: Volleyball physical performance relies on the interaction between mechanical power, metabolic efficiency, and ventilatory regulation during repeated high-intensity actions. This study examined mechanical and cardiopulmonary responses during three consecutive 15 s countermovement jump bouts in female
sub_theme: mechanical-metabolic interactions, cardiopulmonary responses, repeated jumping
ai_summary: Analysis of 18 female volleyball players performing three consecutive 15-second jump bouts revealed progressive mechanical decline (jump height: 20.59 to 19.30 cm) and increasing oxygen uptake (16.40 to 20.87 mL/min/kg), indicating incomplete recovery under short rest conditions and limited oxidative efficiency.

title: Maximal eccentric–concentric strength determines stretch-shortening cycle leg power across biological sexes
abstract: The ratio of eccentric-to-concentric force output (E/C ratio) is higher in female compared to male individuals, however, the functional implications for stretch-shortening cycle (SSC) leg power output remains unknown. Thus, in the present study, male and female competitive athletes (n = 178; females
sub_theme: eccentric-concentric strength, stretch-shortening cycle, sex differences
ai_summary: Eccentric-to-concentric force ratio was 7% higher in female competitive athletes but leg extensor concentric strength, not sex, was the primary determinant of countermovement jump power across sexes.

title: Knowledge and Attitudes of Youth Ice Hockey Players and Their Parents Toward Concussion in the United Kingdom
abstract: Introduction and aim There is a lack of research investigating the knowledge and attitudes of youth ice hockey players and their parents toward concussion in the United Kingdom. This is a topic of increasing concern given the well-known risks associated with contact sports. Previous research in this
sub_theme: concussion knowledge and attitudes
ai_summary: UK youth ice hockey players and parents showed moderate concussion knowledge with parents scoring significantly higher, and a positive correlation between knowledge and safer attitudes toward concussion management in players but not parents.

title: SKATER: Synthesized Kinematics for Advanced Traversing Efficiency on a Humanoid Robot via Roller Skate Swizzles
abstract: Although recent years have seen significant progress of humanoid robots in walking and running, the frequent foot strikes with ground during these locomotion gaits inevitably generate high instantaneous impact forces, which leads to exacerbated joint wear and poor energy utilization. Roller skating,
sub_theme: roller skating gait optimization in humanoid robots
ai_summary: Deep reinforcement learning was applied to optimize swizzle gait mechanics in wheeled humanoid robots, demonstrating 75.86% reduction in impact intensity and 63.34% reduction in cost of transport compared to bipedal walking.

title: The performance, health and development of youth women's footballers: A systematic scoping review
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: The primary aim of this scoping review was to summarise the current scientific literature on the performance, health and development of youth women's footballers. The review provides a summary of the research topics, including methodological approaches adopted and key findings, and identifies gaps i
sub_theme: youth women's football performance, health, development
ai_summary: Systematic scoping review of 294 studies on youth women's footballers identified physical qualities (40%) and injury (17%) as most-studied topics, with significant research gaps in training load, fatigue, and recovery despite rapid growth in literature since 2020.

title: The Effect of Adding Supplemental Abdominal Muscle Strengthening to Improve Expiratory Pulmonary Function: A Pilot Study
abstract: Purpose: Respiratory muscle training can improve strength, endurance, and ventilatory function. Although the rectus abdominis is considered the primary muscle of forced expiration, limited research has been conducted to explore whether adding external oblique (EO), internal oblique (IO), and transve
sub_theme: respiratory muscle training, abdominal core strengthening
ai_summary: Supplemental abdominal muscle strengthening (external oblique, internal oblique, transverse abdominis) showed minimal statistical significance but strong effect sizes in expiratory pulmonary function metrics in female middle/long-distance runners.

title: Thrown off balance: left-handers are under-represented in elite throwing sports
abstract: Abstract Compared to the approximately 10% prevalence of left-handers in the general population, left-handedness is over-represented among athletes in various antagonistic, duel-based sports, such as combat sports (e.g. fencing) and interactive ball games (e.g. table tennis). This over-representatio
sub_theme: left-handedness prevalence, throwing sports
ai_summary: Elite track-and-field throwers (javelin, discus, shot put) show striking under-representation of left-handers (2–5%) compared to 10% population prevalence, suggesting handedness disadvantages in non-antagonistic throwing contexts unlike antagonistic sports.

title: Excessive Q-Angle and its association with sports injury risk: A literature review
journal: International journal of health & medical sciences
abstract: Background: The quadriceps angle (Q-angle) is an anatomical parameter reflecting lower extremity alignment and knee biomechanics. Abnormal or excessive Q-angle has been proposed as an intrinsic risk factor for sports-related injuries, particularly involving the knee joint. Objective: This review aim
sub_theme: Q-angle, patellofemoral pain, knee alignment
ai_summary: A narrative literature review found that excessive Q-angle is associated with altered lower extremity alignment and increased risk of patellofemoral pain syndrome, iliotibial band syndrome, and knee ligament injuries, with higher prevalence in female athletes and high-impact sports.

title: Perceptual gains, performance pains? Massage gun use during warm-up enhances perceived readiness without performance benefits
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: Handheld massage guns are widely used by athletes, however, evidence for their acute effects during warm-up remains limited. Fifty-nine recreational athletes (21.6 ± 2.4 years; 24 female, 35 male) were randomly assigned to a massage gun group (GUN; n = 30) or control group (CON; n = 29). All partici
sub_theme: massage gun, warm-up, performance, perceptual readiness
ai_summary: A randomized controlled trial of 59 recreational athletes found that massage gun use during warm-up enhanced perceived readiness to perform but impaired several countermovement jump metrics and showed no benefits for mobility or sprinting.

title: An observational study of the reliability and concurrent validity of heart rate variability devices in athletes
abstract: Background Heart rate variability (HRV) is a non-invasive indicator of autonomic nervous system function and is increasingly used in athlete monitoring. While electrocardiography (ECG) is the gold standard for HRV measurement, its use is limited in field settings. Objective To evaluate the intra-ses
sub_theme: heart rate variability monitoring, device validation, wearables
ai_summary: An observational study of 37 trained athletes validated a smartphone PPG app and Polar chest strap for heart rate variability measurement, finding both devices showed good reliability and validity compared to ECG, with the chest strap superior in precision but the app offering a practical low-cost alternative.

title: Biomechanics-based analysis of technical characteristics in skeleton start and specific physical training strategies
abstract: Purpose This study employed kinematic and kinetic testing to analyze the sport-specific parameters of the skeleton start, thereby elucidating its technical characteristics and establishing an empirical basis for training. Methods Spatiotemporal parameters were captured using a 3D motion system, whil
sub_theme: skeleton start technique, kinematic analysis, force production
ai_summary: A kinematic and kinetic analysis of skeleton start mechanics in male and female athletes revealed gender differences in starting speed and acceleration, characterized the sport-specific periodic speed-power movements, and recommended training strategies including sprint, push simulations, and core stability work.

title: Peak performance: Participating in intergroup competitions facilitates extraordinary performance
journal: International Journal of Sports Science & Coaching
abstract: This study examines peak performance by focusing on intergroup competitions. It is hypothesized that athletes would show their best ever performance in intergroup competitions more often than in interindividual competitions due to effort gains evoked by performing in a team. Using archival data, the
sub_theme: peak performance, team vs. individual competition, relay swimming
ai_summary: Analysis of 100 fastest swimmers' archival data found that significantly more swimmers achieved their all-time peak performance in relay competitions than individual competitions (68 of 100), even after controlling for relay start benefit, supporting the hypothesis that intergroup competition enhances performance.

title: МЕТОДИЧНІ ПІДХОДИ ДО РОЗВИТКУ СИЛОВИХ ЗДІБНОСТЕЙ ЗДОБУВАЧІВ ВИЩОЇ ОСВІТИ НА ЗАНЯТТЯХ З ДИСЦИПЛІНИ «ТЕОРІЯ І МЕТОДИКА ВИКЛАДАННЯ АТЛЕТИЗМУ»
journal: Physical culture sports and health of the nation
abstract: Abstract. Relevance. Solving the problem of integrating innovative methods into the educational process is positioned as a key priority, ensuring the proper quality of training of specialists in the field of physical culture and sports and intensification of their professional activities. In the con
sub_theme: strength training development in athletics education
ai_summary: Pedagogical experiment with 35 higher education students in Ukraine demonstrates that superset-based strength training program effectively develops maximum strength, explosive power, and strength endurance.

title: Weight Loss Trends in Women’s Wrestling and Potential Implications of Menstrual Cycle: A Narrative Review
abstract: Background/Objectives: Women’s wrestling is one of the fastest growing sports within the United States at the high school and collegiate level. Weight-class sports, such as wrestling, present unique challenges for female athletes, particularly in managing acute weight fluctuations associated with th
sub_theme: weight loss, menstrual cycle, female wrestlers
ai_summary: Narrative review of weight loss trends in female wrestlers reveals sex-specific menstrual cycle effects on fluid retention and body composition that require tailored weight management strategies for this population.

title: Emotional intelligence in shaping junior athletes’ productive coping strategies
abstract: Background and purpose The aim is to study the role and function of junior athletes’ emotional intelligence in shaping productive strategies, including self-control, accepting responsibility, problem-solving planning, positive reappraisal, and social support. Material and methods The sample (n = 120
sub_theme: emotional intelligence, coping strategies, junior athletes
ai_summary: Emotional intelligence predicts productive coping strategies (self-control, problem-solving, positive reappraisal) in junior athletes aged 15–19, with managing emotions influencing self-control and self-motivation influencing acceptance of responsibility.

title: The Cross-Cultural Adaptation, Validation and Psychometric Properties of the Mental Fatigue Scale in Turkish Athletes
abstract: Background/Objective: This study aimed to adapt the Mental Fatigue Scale (MFs) to evaluate the psychometric properties in adult and adolescent athletes. Methods: A total of 491 adolescent and adult athletes (n = 491) consisting of 204 adults (men = 115; female = 90; age = 24.38 ± 3.18 year) and 287
sub_theme: Mental Fatigue Scale validation, Turkish athletes
ai_summary: Cross-cultural adaptation and validation of the Mental Fatigue Scale in Turkish adolescent and adult athletes demonstrated acceptable factorial validity and reliable measurement of general mental fatigue across age groups.

title: Effect of PAPE induced by different squat loads on jump performance in collegiate female basketball players
journal: BMC Sports Science Medicine and Rehabilitation
abstract: Abstract Background Post-activation performance enhancement (PAPE) effectively augments explosive performance, especially in jumping. As female athletes have distinct neuromuscular and biomechanical traits that may affect the PAPE response, the optimal squat load and recovery duration for collegiate
sub_theme: PAPE, squat load, jump performance, female athletes
ai_summary: In collegiate female basketball players, 80% 1RM back-squat with 8–12-minute recovery optimally enhanced jump performance through earlier gastrocnemius activation and stable neuromuscular output compared to 70% or 90% loads.

title: The characteristics of lower extremity muscle activity and static balance of Chinese elite trampoline athletes during net contact phase
abstract: Lower extremity muscle strength and balance control are crucial components in high-level trampolining. However, current research on these aspects remains limited. This study aimed to explore the activity patterns of lower limb muscle groups and the balance characteristics of elite trampoline athlete
sub_theme: lower extremity muscle activity, balance, trampoline athletes
ai_summary: Elite Chinese trampoline athletes show significant gender differences in lower limb dynamics during net contact: males exhibit stronger gastrocnemius activity and left-ward center-of-gravity shift; females show superior right-side balance in closed-eye conditions.

title: Exploring the Identity Representation and Empowerment of Pakistani Women Athletes: An Ethnographic Study of Pakistan Sports Board (PSB), Islamabad
abstract: This study investigates the identity representation and empowerment of Pakistani women athletes through an ethnographic inquiry at the Pakistan Sports Board (PSB), Islamabad. Employing Postcolonial Feminism, particularly Lila Abu-Lughod’s critique of Western-centric narratives of empowerment, the re
sub_theme: identity representation, empowerment, Pakistani women athletes
ai_summary: Ethnographic study of Pakistani women athletes reveals resilience in navigating intersecting barriers (restricted facility access, family pressure, harassment) through subtle resistance and agency negotiation within cultural frameworks, challenging Western-centric empowerment narratives.

title: Dieting, disordered eating and perfectionism in weight-classified combat sports: a pilot study
abstract: Introduction: Weight management through dieting and rapid weight loss (RWL) is central to performance in weight-classified combat sports but may increase the risk of disordered eating (DE). Perfectionism, a common trait among athletes, can have both adaptive and maladaptive effects and contribute to
sub_theme: rapid weight loss, disordered eating, perfectionism
ai_summary: Weight-classified combat sport athletes (kickboxers, BJJ) exhibit low overall disordered eating symptoms (15% above cutoff) despite frequent rapid weight loss practices; both adaptive and maladaptive perfectionism associate with eating disorder symptoms.

title: Tracing strategic divergence: archetypal and counterfactual analysis of StarCraft II gameplay trajectories
abstract: Introduction To address the challenges of data heterogeneity, strategic diversity, and process opacity in interpreting multi-agent decision-making within complex competitive environments, we have developed TRACE, an end-to-end analytical framework for StarCraft II gameplay. Methods This framework st
sub_theme: StarCraft II strategic analysis and gameplay trajectories
ai_summary: TRACE framework using Conditional Recurrent Variational Autoencoder to analyze StarCraft II professional gameplay, identifying strategic deviations in early game (8.4% of match duration) driven by technology timing gaps with 90% similarity improvement in counterfactual alignment.

title: PHYSICAL, PHYSIOLOGICAL, AND PSYCHOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF JUNIOR ROWERS - A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW
journal: Facta Universitatis Series Physical Education and Sport
abstract: This systematic review examines the physical, physiological, and psychological characteristics of junior (U19) rowers. Rowing is a demanding endurance sport that combines aerobic and anaerobic capacity, muscular strength, motor precision, and mental resilience. Following PRISMA guidelines, studies p
sub_theme: junior rowers, talent identification, physical and psychological characteristics, U19 athletes
ai_summary: A systematic review of 20 studies on U19 rowers identifies key anthropometric, aerobic, anaerobic, motor, and psychological characteristics associated with 2000m ergometer performance, emphasizing integrated development of aerobic capacity, strength training, and psychological resilience for talent identification.

title: Sex Differences in Severity and Recovery Following Mild Traumatic Brain Injury: A Systematic Review
abstract: Background: Sex-based variations in brain structure, hormonal balance, and neurochemistry may influence symptom presentation and recovery after mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). This systematic review investigated sex-related differences in mTBI severity, symptoms, and recovery outcomes across dif
sub_theme: mild traumatic brain injury, concussion, sex differences
ai_summary: A systematic review of 41 studies (15,656 participants) showing females report greater symptom burden, longer recovery times, and more extensive white matter alterations than males following mild traumatic brain injury.

title: Treatment of Second and Third Carpometacarpal Joint Instability in Elite Boxers
journal: The Journal of Hand Surgery (Asian-Pacific Volume)
abstract: Background: Instability of the second and third carpometacarpal joints (CMCJs) is a rare disorder. This study aimed to present treatment outcomes of CMCJ instability in elite boxers. Methods: Combat-sport athletes with second and third CMCJ instability treated at our hospital between 2011 and 2023 w
sub_theme: carpometacarpal joint instability, hand injuries in boxers, surgical treatment
ai_summary: Retrospective case series of 20 elite boxers (19 male, 1 female) with carpometacarpal joint instability treated conservatively (7) or surgically (13); all returned to pre-injury competition level pain-free using IK classification-based strategy with single-screw arthrodesis.

title: The application of principal component analysis to distinguish the kinematics parameters of hammer throw technique among athletes of varying levels participating in the European Throwing Cup for the years 2018 and 2022
abstract: The hammer throw is a complex discipline event in track and field sports, where Principal Component Analysis (PCA) has been applied as a key tool to analyse the details of movement patterns and identify crucial factors that affect performance. Therefore, this study aimed to use the PCA to analyse th
sub_theme: hammer throw kinematics, principal component analysis, technique analysis
ai_summary: Principal component analysis of 3D kinematics from 71 hammer throwers (39 male, 32 female) at European Throwing Cup revealed that Turn 4 velocity, amplitude, and timing were critical performance factors, with age/gender-specific technique recommendations.

title: Sweat sodium composition and sweat loss estimation through wearable sensors and predictive equations in dry and humid hot conditions
abstract: Introduction Individualized sweat testing is essential for tailoring hydration and nutrition strategies, as water and sodium losses during exercise vary greatly across athletes. The validity of a wearable sweat sensor (S1, Flowbio) and a handheld analyzer (LAQUAtwin, Horiba Advanced Techno) for meas
sub_theme: sweat sodium, hydration assessment
ai_summary: Wearable sweat sensor (S1) provided equivalent sweat sodium measurement to handheld analyzer and accurate whole-body sweat loss estimation during cycling in hot/humid conditions, validating its practical use for individualized hydration strategies.

title: Impact of Proximal Conjoint Tendon Injury on Return to Play in the BF–ST Complex: A Prospective MRI-Based Study
abstract: Background/Objectives: Proximal hamstring injuries involving the biceps femoris–semitendinosus (BF–ST) conjoint tendon (CT) often exhibit delayed healing, yet the prognostic significance of CT involvement and intratendinous injury morphology has not been fully clarified. This study aimed to determin
sub_theme: hamstring conjoint tendon injury; return-to-play prognosis
ai_summary: A prospective MRI-based study of 41 university rugby players found that full-layer biceps femoris–semitendinosus conjoint tendon injuries, particularly with bilateral involvement, required approximately twice as long return-to-play (11.4 weeks) compared to isolated injuries (4–5 weeks).

title: Impact of Injury on Anxiety, Depression, and Quality of Life in Youth Soccer Players
abstract: Objective: The purpose of this cross-sectional study was to evaluate associations among injury, quality of life (QOL), and mental health among elite youth soccer athletes. Design: Study materials were sent to Elite Clubs National League (ECNL) clubs through an online survey link. Setting: Soccer ath
sub_theme: mental health and quality of life outcomes post-injury in youth soccer
ai_summary: A cross-sectional study of 668 elite youth soccer athletes (ECNL) found that currently injured players reported significantly higher anxiety and depression and lower quality of life than uninjured players, with negative psychosocial impacts persisting even after return to play.

title: An Unusual Cause of Buttock Pain in a Collegiate Football Player: A Septic Sacroiliac Joint
abstract: Early recognition of sacroiliac (SI) joint infection can be challenging in young, otherwise healthy individuals presenting with nonspecific buttock or thigh pain. We present the case of a 21-year-old collegiate football player who developed progressive buttock and thigh pain after a minor fall durin
sub_theme: septic sacroiliac joint infection; return-to-play case
ai_summary: A case report of a 21-year-old collegiate football player with septic sacroiliitis caused by methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus, highlighting diagnostic challenges of joint infection in young athletes and demonstrating full recovery with prompt antibiotic therapy and return to play after three months.

title: Case Study: Prevalence of Hip Pain and Femoroacetabular Impingement in Professional Table Tennis Players
abstract: Objective: To (1) report the prevalence of hip pain in professional table tennis players registered at a National Sports Institute, (2) describe their hip pathologies, and (3) evaluate expectations regarding hip pain before and after becoming high-level athletes. Design: Case series. Setting: French
sub_theme: femoroacetabular impingement, hip pathology
ai_summary: A case series documenting 58% prevalence of hip pain and 42% prevalence of femoroacetabular impingement in 19 professional table tennis players, with 26% requiring surgical intervention.

title: BD Sports-10: A comprehensive video dataset for Bangladeshi sports classification and analysis
abstract: Bangladesh has diverse and vibrant cultural sports, some of which have gained international recognition in recent years. However, there is a lack of standardized datasets for deep learning and computer vision tasks. To address this gap, BD Sports-10 was developed as a comprehensive dataset for Bangl
sub_theme: Bangladeshi traditional sports video dataset for classification and analysis
ai_summary: BD Sports-10 dataset comprises 3,000 videos of ten Bangladeshi traditional sports with standardized resolution and frame rates, enabling deep learning and computer vision research for sport classification, object detection, and player tracking.

title: Assessment of Temporomandibular Disorders, Oral Health Status, Knowledge and Hygiene Behaviours Among Athletes in Croatia: A Cross-Sectional Study
abstract: Aim: This study aimed to assess self-reported oral and orofacial health, hygiene habits, and oral health knowledge among Croatian athletes, and to determine factors influencing that knowledge. Differences between contact and non-contact sports, as well as the occurrence of dental trauma and temporom
sub_theme: oral health, temporomandibular disorders, dental trauma in athletes
ai_summary: Cross-sectional study of 1,007 Croatian athletes found moderate oral health knowledge (11.3/18), good brushing habits (86.9%), but low flossing compliance (25.4%), with no significant differences between contact and non-contact sports.

title: Optimising Recovery Intervals for Post-Activation Performance Enhancement: A Systematic Review of Vertical Jump Outcomes
abstract: Background. Post-activation performance enhancement (PAPE) is widely used to acutely improve explosive capabilities; however, reported outcomes vary substantially due to differences in protocol design, population characteristics, and recovery strategies. Purpose. This systematic review aimed to synt
sub_theme: post-activation performance enhancement, vertical jump, recovery intervals
ai_summary: Systematic review of 31 studies (2015-2025) showed PAPE protocols improved countermovement jump by 1.5-12% (median +6%), with moderate recovery intervals (3-7 min) most reliable; heavy-load squats and variable resistance yielded largest gains.

title: Prevalence of Musculoskeletal Injuries in Volleyball Players with a Focus on Lower Limbs and the Predictive Value of the Tuck Jump Assessment: A Cross-sectional Study
journal: Journal of Clinical Research in Paramedical Sciences
abstract: Background: Volleyball involves repetitive jumping and landing, which predispose athletes to lower limb injuries. Functional performance tests, such as the Tuck Jump Assessment (TJA), have been proposed as screening tools to identify athletes at risk. Objectives: The present study primarily aimed to
sub_theme: lower limb injury prevalence, Tuck Jump Assessment, screening
ai_summary: Cross-sectional study of 139 youth volleyball players found 27% injury prevalence with knee (31%), ankle (24%), and shoulder (15%) most affected; age, height, weight, and training experience predicted injury risk, but Tuck Jump Assessment did not (P=0.12).

title: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Anterior Cruciate Ligament Injury Prevention Programs: Training to Stay in the Game
journal: The American Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Background: Approximately 400,000 anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstructions are performed each year in the United States. Effective ACL injury prevention programs may be paramount in reducing this significant injury burden. Purpose: To determine the effectiveness of ACL injury prevention prog
sub_theme: ACL injury prevention programs, neuromuscular training
ai_summary: Meta-analysis of 18 studies (25,166 athletes, >85% female) showed ACL prevention programs reduced ACL rupture risk by 54% (RR 0.46, 95% CI 0.36-0.57), with greater efficacy in females (RR 0.57) and soccer/handball players (RR 0.30-0.66).

title: External Load in High-Level Tennis Training: Influence of Game-Specific Drills in Junior and Professional Players Across Playing Situations
abstract: This study explored the influence of game-specific on-court drills on external load in junior and professional male tennis players. Using wearable inertial technology, a total of 345 drills performed during a training microcycle were analyzed. Drills were classified according to the usual tennis gam
sub_theme: external load, game-specific drills, training demands
ai_summary: Analysis of 345 on-court tennis drills using wearable inertial technology found that baseline and all-court drills produced highest external load demands, with juniors covering more distance than professionals but professionals showing greater acceleration/deceleration values.

title: Effects of high-intensity interval training on aerobic capacity and muscle adaptation: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: Background and purpose High-intensity interval training (HIIT) is widely implemented in sport and exercise settings to enhance aerobic capacity and induce muscular adaptations. However, findings are dispersed across diverse protocols and populations, and the relative effectiveness of different HIIT
sub_theme: high-intensity interval training effects on aerobic capacity and muscle adaptation
ai_summary: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 24 controlled trials shows high-intensity interval training produces moderate improvements in aerobic capacity comparable to or greater than moderate-intensity continuous training, with heterogeneous but generally beneficial effects on muscular oxidative capacity.

title: Time pressure and player disadvantage: Effects on jump performance in simulated matches of well-trained amateur handball players
journal: Journal of Coaching and Sports Science
abstract: Background: At the end of a handball match, when players are physically disadvantaged and pressured by time, their overall fitness declines. This primarily affects their jumping ability, a key skill for scoring points. Aims: This study examined the effects of late-match time pressure and player disa
sub_theme: time pressure, fatigue, jumping performance
ai_summary: Jumping performance (countermovement jump height, rate of force development, power) increased significantly after simulated handball matches regardless of player disadvantage, showing no consistent fatigue-induced decline under time pressure.

title: Sex differences in electrocardiograms of trained athletes: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: Abstract Aims To describe and quantify sex differences in the screening electrocardiograms (ECGs) of athletes. Methods and results Five databases (MEDLINE, EMBASE, Scopus, SPORTDiscus, and Web of Science) were searched from inception until October 2024. Included studies were original research articl
sub_theme: sex differences in athlete electrocardiograms, sudden cardiac death screening
ai_summary: Meta-analysis of 85 studies (19,069 female and 57,745 male athletes) found female athletes twice as likely to have abnormal T-wave inversion and six times more likely to have isolated TWI in V1-V3, with no associated cardiac pathology diagnoses.

title: Biomechanical analysis of the push-up exercise in university male student-athletes from different specializations: a sport-based comparative study
abstract: Introduction: Sport-specific training may shape the neuromuscular strategies used in fundamental movements such as the push-up. Objective: To compare the kinematic, kinetic, and electromyographic characteristics of push-ups among athletes from gymnastics, swimming, track and field, and basketball. M
sub_theme: push-up kinematics, sport-specific motor control
ai_summary: Comparative biomechanical analysis of push-ups in 80 male athletes from gymnastics, swimming, track, and basketball revealed sport-specific neuromuscular signatures: gymnasts showed superior trunk stability, swimmers greater shoulder mobility, and sprinters/basketball players higher force development.

title: Quantifying perceived stress and burnout of NCAA division I athletic department support staff members
abstract: Employment in collegiate athletics often involves a fast-paced, high-pressure, stressful environment for employees that may lead to the development of burnout. This study examined the perceived stress and burnout of support staff members (e.g., athletic training, marketing). Surveys were delivered t
sub_theme: burnout, perceived stress, athletic department support staff
ai_summary: NCAA Division I athletic department support staff (n=314) reported moderate perceived stress and personal/work-related burnout with positive correlations between stress and all burnout dimensions; staff with regular student-athlete interaction reported higher personal burnout.

title: Decreased Hip Strength Leads to Altered Dynamic Motion Biomechanics in Healthy Female Athletes
journal: The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: Abstract Freemyer, B, Takata, A, Kim, Y, and Stickley, C. Decreased hip strength leads to altered dynamic motion biomechanics in healthy female athletes. J Strength Cond Res XX(X): 000–000, 2025—The posterolateral hip muscles are essential for tasks that require dynamic ability. Weakness is associat
sub_theme: hip strength, landing mechanics, injury prevention, female athletes
ai_summary: Forty-six female athletes with decreased hip strength showed significantly altered drop vertical jump landing biomechanics (13° less hip flexion, 9.7° less knee flexion, 7.6° less anterior pelvic tilt) but no differences in side-cutting, suggesting hip strength assessment may improve injury prevention screening.

title: Sex-Based Performance Differences in Shot Put, Javelin, and Long Jump Among U.S. Youth Athletes Aged 10 Years and Under
journal: The Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: Abstract Brown, GA, Shaw, BS, and Shaw, I. Sex-based performance differences in shot put, javelin, and long jump among U.S. youth athletes aged 10 and under. J Strength Cond Res XX(X): 000–000, 2025—Controversy currently exists over whether sex-based differences necessitate sex-segregated youth spor
sub_theme: sex-based performance differences, youth athletes, throwing and jumping events
ai_summary: Analysis of USA Track & Field Regional Junior Olympic Championships data (2022-2024) revealed significant sex-based performance differences in prepubertal athletes (8-10 years) across javelin (Hedges' g=1.1-1.14), shot put (g=0.73-0.74), and long jump (g=0.43-0.47), with males outperforming females by 8-55% depending on event.

title: The Effect of Plyometric Training on Ability Javelin Throw by Pasi Sleman Athletes
journal: International Journal of Innovative Science and Research Technology (IJISRT)
abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of plyometric training on the javelin throwing ability of PASI Sleman athletes. This study is a pre-experimental study with a "One Group Pre-test Post-test Design" design. The study was conducted at Tridadi Stadium, Sleman, from February 3 to Mar
sub_theme: plyometric training, javelin throw, training effects
ai_summary: Plyometric training over 16 sessions improved javelin throwing ability in 10 PASI Sleman athletes (ages 14-20): overall increase of 4.116 meters (14.99%), with female athletes improving 9.41% and male athletes 10.19%.

title: The impact of sport engagement on life satisfaction, mental and psychological well-being among athletes
abstract: Physical inactivity is a prevalent issue worldwide with concerning implications for public health. Regular participation in sporting activities is associated with numerous physical, psychological, and social benefits. This research aimed to examine the the impact of sport engagement on sportive life
sub_theme: sport engagement, life satisfaction, mental well-being
ai_summary: Sport engagement significantly predicted sportive life satisfaction, mental well-being, and psychological well-being among 473 Turkish athletes across multiple disciplines using correlation and regression analysis.

title: Analysis of the Dominant Physical Capacity Components of Volleyball Players in the Train to Train Phase
abstract: The purpose of this study was to identify the most important physical components in volleyball, using a non-experimental quantitative descriptive approach. The sample consisted of 54 athletes aged 12 - 16 years from the Active Movement Volleyball School (AMVS), selected using purposive sampling. The
sub_theme: physical capacity assessment, youth volleyball
ai_summary: Descriptive analysis of 54 youth volleyball players (ages 12-16) showed good physical condition profiles across most biomotor components, with leg power and strength dominating at 68-77% in the good category.

title: Addressing Gender Inequity in Australian Sports Leadership: A Postfeminist Policy Paradox
journal: Journal of Sport and Social Issues
abstract: Despite the growth in women's sport, decision-making positions in sports organizations remain dominated by men. This paper examines efforts to improve gender balance in roles of leadership using two Australian governing bodies as case studies. To understand how organizations address gender dispariti
sub_theme: gender balance in sports leadership and coaching
ai_summary: Case study analysis of two Australian sports governing bodies shows gender equity initiatives focus on individual skill development rather than institutional structural change, perpetuating leadership disparities.

title: Revolutionizing Athlete Management in the Indian Sporting Industry
journal: Zenodo (CERN European Organization for Nuclear Research)
abstract: In the following paper, the design and implemen- tation are presented. of a safe, role based Athlete Management System (AMS) customized to the Indian sporting environment. The system supports there are four different logins: Athlete, Coach, Organization/Event Manager, and Dietician. At the core leve
sub_theme: athlete management system design
ai_summary: Design and implementation of a role-based Athlete Management System for Indian sports with modules for performance tracking, training schedules, nutrition management, and communication.

title: Revolutionizing Athlete Management in the Indian Sporting Industry
journal: Zenodo (CERN European Organization for Nuclear Research)
abstract: In the following paper, the design and implemen- tation are presented. of a safe, role based Athlete Management System (AMS) customized to the Indian sporting environment. The system supports there are four different logins: Athlete, Coach, Organization/Event Manager, and Dietician. At the core leve
sub_theme: athlete management system design
ai_summary: Design and implementation of a role-based Athlete Management System for Indian sports with modules for performance tracking, training schedules, nutrition management, and communication.

title: A Machine Learning Framework for Off Ball Defensive Role and Performance Evaluation in Football
abstract: Evaluating off-ball defensive performance in football is challenging, as traditional metrics do not capture the nuanced coordinated movements that limit opponent action selection and success probabilities. Although widely used possession value models excel at appraising on-ball actions, their applic
sub_theme: off-ball defense, hidden markov models, corner kicks
ai_summary: Covariate-dependent Hidden Markov Model applied to tracking data inferred man-marking and zonal defensive assignments from corner kicks, enabling context-aware credit attribution and counterfactual evaluation of off-ball defensive performance.

title: Functional Asymmetries in Youth Soccer Players: A Systematic Review of Assessment Technologies and Artificial Intelligence Applications
abstract: Background. Functional asymmetries in youth soccer players represent an important biomechanical and neuromuscular phenomenon, acting both as adaptive mechanisms and as potential risk factors for injury. However, existing evidence remains fragmented regarding the effectiveness of technological and ar
sub_theme: functional asymmetries, AI-based assessment, wearable technology
ai_summary: A systematic review of 28 studies found that AI-based models and wearable technologies can assess functional asymmetries in youth soccer players, with strength asymmetries exceeding 15% significantly associated with increased injury risk.

title: Altered gait biomechanics after peroneus longus tendon harvest for anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction
abstract: Aims The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of peroneus longus tendon (PLT) harvest on gait biomechanics following anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction. There is scarce evidence in the literature about the safety of PLT as a potential graft for ACL reconstruction, and no long-te
sub_theme: ACL reconstruction, graft harvest, gait biomechanics, rehabilitation
ai_summary: Peroneus longus tendon harvest for ACL reconstruction resulted in subtle gait alterations including prolonged single-leg support time despite overall functional improvements, suggesting need for targeted ankle rehabilitation in athletes.

title: Gender, authority and the role of the referee in sportjournalism
journal: KTH Publication Database DiVA (KTH Royal Institute of Technology)
abstract: This study examines how female football referees are represented in Swedish sports journalism between 2020 and 2025. Despite growing research on gender and media, the representation of referees, particularly women, remains understudied. Using a qualitative framing analysis of thirteen news and opini
sub_theme: media representation of female referees
ai_summary: Swedish sports journalism systematically frames female football referees as pioneers or emotionally exposed actors while depicting male referees as neutral technical experts, reproducing gendered norms that constrain women's legitimacy in authoritative roles.

title: Perfiles de cargo y equidad de género en las organizaciones deportivas de orden departamental
abstract: This research addressed job profiles and gender equity in regional sports organizations (SOs) in Colombia. The study was developed under a Sequential Mixed Approach, with a descriptive scope. The final effective sample was composed of the executives and formal documents of Indeportes Antioquia, the
sub_theme: gender equity in regional sports organizations
ai_summary: Study of three Colombian regional sports organizations shows structured job profiles exist but men occupy 80% of decision-making positions; significant progress in formal hiring equality driven by quota law, though cultural stereotypes and gender violence response capacity remain major challenges.

title: Age, Workload, and Usage Rate: Risk Factors Associated With Knee Injuries in Women’s National Basketball Association Athletes
abstract: Background: Knee injuries are among the most common injuries in female basketball players. Despite the growing popularity of professional women's basketball, particularly the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA), there are limited recent data evaluating the incidence of and risk factors fo
sub_theme: knee injury epidemiology
ai_summary: Epidemiological analysis of WNBA players (2017–2022) found knee injury incidence of 6.03 per 1000 minutes-exposures, with older age and higher usage rate as significant risk factors.

title: Voices of Change: A Qualitative Analysis of the Motivations Behind Female Athlete Activism at Tokyo 2020
abstract: This study investigates the motivations of intersectionally marginalized female athletes engaging in activism during the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games. Using qualitative content analysis of secondary-sourced interviews with three U.S. Olympians, the research identifies five areas influencing activist beh
sub_theme: motivations for athlete activism and marginalized identities
ai_summary: Qualitative analysis of intersectionally marginalized female U.S. Olympians at Tokyo 2020 identified that psychological needs for autonomy, competence, and belonging, combined with socialization, drive athlete activism behaviors.

title: Analysis of technical performance of pencak silat athletes in the sparring category of men's class c, men's class e and women's class b at malang state university
abstract: This research aims to find out the technical performance of pencak silat athletes in the sparring category of class C men, class E men and class B women of State University of Malang through performance analysis. This research uses descriptive qualitative methods with Visual Research Method techniqu
sub_theme: technical performance in pencak silat sparring
ai_summary: Video analysis of pencak silat athletes across three weight classes revealed that the sickle kick was the dominant technique (33-39% of actions) with 70-85% success rates, with left-sided execution showing higher effectiveness.

title: Acute effects of dietary whey protein supplementation after endurance exercise on serum osteokine and inflammatory cytokine concentrations in endurance runners
abstract: Endurance athletes have an increased risk of bone stress injuries due to high training and energy demands. Endurance training with inadequate recovery triggers a pro-inflammatory response, which can upregulate bone resorption for hours to days. Combined dietary protein and carbohydrate supplementati
sub_theme: whey protein supplementation and bone resorption in endurance runners
ai_summary: A randomized controlled trial in young endurance runners found that acute post-exercise whey protein supplementation did not significantly attenuate bone resorption or inflammatory cytokine responses compared to control after exhaustive running.

title: A246: Epidemiological Characteristics of Injury Among Chinese Rowing Athletes
journal: International Journal of Physical Activity and Health
abstract: To develop a prevention program for rowing-related injuries, it is crucial to study the epidemiological characteristics of injury among Chinese rowing athletes. This study aimed to investigate the distribution and incidence of injuries among Chinese rowing athletes aged 12-24. A cross-sectional stud
sub_theme: injury incidence and patterns in Chinese rowing athletes
ai_summary: A cross-sectional study of 207 Chinese rowing athletes found an overall injury rate of 38.2% with lower back injuries most common (39.7%), and female athletes over 18 years experiencing significantly higher injury rates per training session (7.85/1000) compared to younger males.

title: Leveraging the Enhanced Sports as a Laboratory Assessment Model to Cross-Validate a Formula Used to Predict Clinical Recovery From Concussion in Collegiate Athletes
abstract: Context The Sports as a Laboratory Assessment Model (SLAM + ) allows for point-of-care data collection to improve outcomes after concussion and assist with clinical research. Objective To cross-validate a prognostic formula to predict clinical recovery in collegiate athletes with concussion leveragi
sub_theme: concussion recovery prediction in collegiate athletes
ai_summary: Cross-validation of a prognostic formula for concussion recovery in 133 collegiate athletes found weak predictive accuracy, with only 30.4% correctly classified for 14-day recovery but 80.6% correctly identified for prolonged recovery (≥15 days).

title: A207: AI Era and Sports Equity
journal: International Journal of Physical Activity and Health
abstract: This study explores the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on sports equity and inclusion, focusing on its use in training, officiating, and talent selection. AI includes technologies like AI-driven training tools and systems, such as VAR. While AI can enhance access to sports resources, it may
sub_theme: AI's impact on sports equity, inclusion, and gender representation
ai_summary: Qualitative analysis of AI use in university sports found that while AI-driven training tools improved accessibility, AI in officiating and talent selection reinforced inequalities, with AI metrics favoring male performance over female athletes and well-funded programs.

title: Discoprins & Powerbrud : A critical discourse analysis of how gender is portrayed in Swedish digital news media during the 2025 World Athletics Championships
abstract: Sports journalism is a big part of today's media landscape and previous studies have shown differences in how female and male athletes in athletics are portrayed in sports journalism, but few have been done in a current Swedish context. The aim of this study is to investigate, through a critical dis
sub_theme: gender representation in sports journalism coverage
ai_summary: Critical discourse analysis of 160 Swedish news articles about World Athletics Championships 2025 revealed systematic gender differences in coverage, with female athletes receiving more focus on emotions and private life versus male athletes' technical performance.

title: A231: Effects of a Six-Week Pre-Competition Program on Blood Biomarkers in Female Adolescent Rowers
journal: International Journal of Physical Activity and Health
abstract: Rowing is a high-intensity cyclic endurance sport that demands precise regulation of training loads to optimize performance. Adolescent athletes undergoing rapid growth and endocrine changes may respond differently to training than adults. However, most current research focuses on adult rowers, with
sub_theme: blood biomarkers, hematological adaptation, endocrine response
ai_summary: Six-week pre-competition training in adolescent female rowers produced significant increases in RBC, MCV, testosterone, and T/C ratio while maintaining all markers within clinical norms, indicating beneficial physiological adaptation.

title: “Each Athlete Is Very Different, and This Is Why I’m Still Learning Every Day”: Experiences of Coaching Elite Athletes With Intellectual Disability and/or Autism
abstract: The aim of this qualitative study was to explore the experiences of coaches working at the elite level with athletes with intellectual disabilities (ID) and/or autism. Moreover, the existing gaps in knowledge and skills necessary for effective coaching were explored. Semistructured interviews and fo
sub_theme: elite coaches, intellectual disability, autism, specialized coaching
ai_summary: Qualitative analysis of 24 elite coaches revealed significant interpersonal, environmental, and sport-specific challenges when coaching athletes with intellectual disabilities and/or autism, highlighting the need for specialized coach education.

title: Motor competence explains the variance in biomechanical variables related to anterior cruciate ligament injury risk, with distinct predictors for male and female athletes
abstract: Abstract Purpose Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries have consistently been linked to specific kinetic and kinematic patterns, including elevated vertical ground reaction forces, increased knee abduction angle and moment (dynamic valgus), reduced knee flexion during landing and excessive hip a
sub_theme: ACL injury risk, biomechanics, motor competence, landing mechanics
ai_summary: Motor competence explained 69.6% of variance in kinetic and kinematic variables associated with ACL injury risk (knee flexion angle, knee abduction angle) in elite basketball, volleyball, and handball athletes, with distinct gender-specific predictors.

title: A087: Assessment of Table Tennis Stroke Effectiveness Using the Artificial Intelligence Technology-Based Algorithm
journal: International Journal of Physical Activity and Health
abstract: Using Artificial intelligence to assist sports training is a hallmark of the information age. Table tennis, a popular sport in China and worldwide, can also benefit from the latest technological advancements in learning and training. Objective: This study aims to quantitatively evaluate the effectiv
sub_theme: table tennis, stroke effectiveness, skill assessment
ai_summary: Dynamic time-warping AI algorithm successfully distinguished skill levels in table tennis forehand strokes between beginner and intermediate players (Cohen's d=0.86), with DTW values correlating with coach evaluations of stroke effectiveness.

title: The Feasibility and Preliminary Effectiveness of a 6-Week Independent Cadence Retraining Program on Parous Runners With Stress Urinary Incontinence
journal: Journal of Women s & Pelvic Health Physical Therapy
abstract: Background: Running often elicits stress urinary incontinence (SUI) in parous athletes. While cadence retraining improves running biomechanics, its impact on incontinence is unclear. This feasibility study assessed the implementation and preliminary effects of a 6-week cadence retraining program in
sub_theme: stress urinary incontinence, cadence retraining, running biomechanics
ai_summary: Six-week cadence retraining program significantly increased running cadence and decreased vertical oscillation in parous female runners with stress urinary incontinence, with concomitant improvements in incontinence symptoms.

title: From amenorrhea to pregnancy: spontaneous recovery of the female athlete triad during the COVID-19 pandemic
abstract: The Female Athlete Triad (Triad) and Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (RED-S) are conditions associated with low energy availability (EA) that can lead to menstrual dysfunction, impaired bone health, and metabolic disturbances. This case report describes the remission of Triad in a professional t
sub_theme: relative energy deficiency, female athlete triad, menstrual dysfunction, bone health
ai_summary: Case report of a professional triathlete with hypothalamic amenorrhea due to relative energy deficiency showing spontaneous remission of female athlete triad and restoration of menstrual function following pandemic-induced reduction in training and improved dietary intake.

title: The Role of Cannabidiol in Sport: Mechanistic Insights, Ergogenic Potential, and Regulatory Implications
abstract: Cannabidiol (CBD), a non-intoxicating constituent of the Cannabis Sativa plant, has gained popularity amongst athletes for its purported therapeutic potential related to analgesia, inflammation and anxiety. In 2018, CBD was removed from the World AntiDoping Agency’s (WADA) list of prohibited substan
sub_theme: cannabidiol, CBD supplementation, anti-doping, ergogenic effects
ai_summary: Comprehensive investigation of cannabidiol in sport found that broad-spectrum CBD supplementation did not enhance cycling performance and posed significant anti-doping risk by introducing prohibited cannabinoids in urine, especially when combined with moderate-intensity exercise.

title: The Relationship Between Hand Dominance and ACL Tears in Competitive Volleyball Athletes
abstract: Background: Knee injuries are common in volleyball athletes, often resulting from the sport's unique movement requirements. Among these, anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears are particularly prevalent, and while the existing literature has examined risk factors such as biomechanical asymmetries an
sub_theme: ACL tears, hand dominance, laterality, biomechanical risk factors
ai_summary: Cross-sectional study of 149 competitive volleyball players revealed significant association between hand dominance and ACL tear laterality, with right-handed players predominantly tearing their left ACL (81.62%) and left-handed players their right ACL (84.62%).

title: Psychological skills training as a strategy to improve mental health and reduce perceived stress in university athletes
abstract: This study examined the effectiveness of a one-month Psychological Skills Training (PST) program in improving mental health and reducing perceived stress among university athletes. Twenty-one student-athletes (15 males and 6 females) from six faculties participated in eight structured PST sessions c
sub_theme: psychological skills training, stress reduction
ai_summary: A one-month psychological skills training program significantly reduced perceived stress in university athletes (mean PSS-10 decreased from 24.14 to 16.81, d=1.30), with high-stress athletes dropping from 38% to 4.8%.

title: Analysis of sports injuries in the implementation of the new 2023 regulations for the sport of Pencak Silat in the 17-35 age category
abstract: Background: The changes to the 2022/2023 Pencak Silat competition rules established by PESILAT are aimed at international standardization, but these changes have the potential to affect patterns and injury risks for athletes in competition categories involving intense physical contact. Objectives: T
sub_theme: injury incidence, Pencak Silat, gender differences
ai_summary: In 30 competitive Pencak Silat athletes, sprains (22%) and bruises (19.5%) were most common injuries with lower extremities most affected; 64% reported that 2023 rule changes increased injury risk.

title: Long-term Outcomes After Hip Arthroscopy for Femoroacetabular Impingement Syndrome in Master Athletes: A Propensity-Matched Study With Mean 10-Year Follow-up
journal: The American Journal of Sports Medicine
abstract: Background: Master athletes (MAs), defined as those aged ≥35 years actively participating in sports, have demonstrated superior short-term outcomes and reoperation-free survivorship after hip arthroscopy (HA) for femoroacetabular impingement syndrome (FAIS) compared with nonathletic counterparts; ho
sub_theme: hip arthroscopy outcomes, femoroacetabular impingement, master athletes
ai_summary: Master athletes (≥35 years, weekly sports participation) showed superior long-term patient-reported outcomes and reoperation-free survivorship at 10-year follow-up after hip arthroscopy for femoroacetabular impingement compared to propensity-matched non-athletic controls.

title: A243: The Relationship Among Sport Confidence, Failure Coping, and Athletic Motivation of Students in Physical Education
journal: International Journal of Physical Activity and Health
abstract: In the research on the psychological abilities in sports competitions, exploring sports motivation is indispensable. Sports motivation has the functions of stimulating students' sports behaviors, guiding students to choose sports events, and strengthening and maintaining students' participation in s
sub_theme: sport confidence, failure coping, athletic motivation
ai_summary: In 897 physical education students, trait and state sport confidence were positively correlated (r=0.409), failure coping dimensions positively intercorrelated (r=0.255-0.401), and participation and avoidance motivation tendencies positively related (r=0.329).

title: Physical Therapy Patient-Reported Outcome Measures for the Female Athlete With Urinary Incontinence: A Scoping Review
journal: Journal of Women s & Pelvic Health Physical Therapy
abstract: Background: Female athletes (FAs) have been shown to have a higher prevalence of urinary incontinence (UI) than nonathletes. Within the field of urogynecology and pelvic health, there are many patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs). In 2014, there was a call for a psychometrically strong PROM for
sub_theme: urinary incontinence, female athletes, patient-reported outcome measures
ai_summary: A scoping review of 35 publications found zero psychometrically validated patient-reported outcome measures specifically for female athletes with urinary incontinence, indicating a significant gap in assessment tools for this population.

title: Identifying individual playing roles in professional and semi-professional male and female basketball players: a systematic review
abstract: Introduction. Basketball is a globally popular sport requiring optimization of players’ physical, physiological, psychological, and tactical performance. Traditional position-based classifications (guards, forwards, centers) are often inadequate to reflect players’ tactical behavior. Recent studies
sub_theme: individual playing roles, position classification, game-related statistics
ai_summary: A systematic review of 12 studies on basketball playing roles identified seven recurrent individual playing roles but found methodological heterogeneity, highlighting the need for standardized frameworks to identify roles using game-related statistics.

title: Women's participation in sport and physical activity in Saudi Arabia: an intersectional study
abstract: Women's participation in sport and physical activity in Saudi Arabia: an intersectional study
sub_theme: women's participation in sport and physical activity
ai_summary: Intersectional analysis of women's participation in sport and physical activity in Saudi Arabia, examining socio-cultural barriers and opportunities.
